HBG aide: Someone wants to bury JFK probe 

SPfcCIAL T O THf t XPRT SS 
WASHINGTON, D C. — The move to end the H ouse A ssassination Com­ mittee is aimed ut killing the John F. 
Kennedy m u r d e r investigation* a sjMtkesmtn tor I S. Rep. Henry B. 
Gonzalez said Thursday. 
" I f s incredible what’s happening 

 here.” the spokesman said. “ There's every indication that plenty of people are running seared.” 
G onzalez. c h a irm a n of the controversial co m m ittee , shocked many in Congress W ednesday* w hen he suddenly resigned in the midst of a battle with Chiel Counsel 
Richard 

' Sprague. 
The spokesman said. “ There's an undercurrent behind the desire to terminate the committee, and that's to kill the Kennedy investigation. 
“ Some efforts are under way to keep the (Martin Luther) King Investigation open. mainly to appease black voters. 

But they definitely want to keep the status quo on the Kennedy killing." 
Gonzalez, confined with illness to his 
San Antonio home, was unavailable for comment. Gail Beagle, Gonzalez’ ad­ ministrative assistant, said he was expected in Washington, D.C.. next week. 

Numerous reports, verified by con­ gressional workers, indicate several 
Congressmen on the committee are afraid of Sprague. 
They fear what Sprague might di­ vulge if he is fired in a showdown with 
Gonzalez on the House floor, one worker said. 

He would not speculate on just what information Sprague might release, however. 
House Speaker Thomas O’Neill said 
Gonzalez’ resignation could be accept­ ed only by a vote of the full House, hut 

CLERK CAPTIVE 

By CECIL (LIFT 
A teen-aged sporting g o o d s store clerk was abducted al gunpoint by a customer using a gun shown hun by the clerk, police reported Thursday night. 
The teen-ager was still missing early 
Friday morning. 
The bizarre incident — which police 

 said had no apparent motive — oc­ curred about 8 p.m. at O sh m an ’s 
Sporting Goods, 727 NU HIHO near 
Blanco Road. 
According to accounts given police, a young blond man walked into the store and began talking with clerk Steve 
Smith, 19. about the purchase of a gun. 
-The customer reportedly w as exa­ 

 mining a .357 magnum pistol when a moment later, he brandished it in the direction of Smith and ordered the clerk outside, witnesses said. 
Once outside Smith was forced into his own car, described as a 19H5 or 19H(i w hite C hevro let 
M alibu with a primer-red hood.

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Friday March 4 1977 
Jean Stapleton favors 
ERA for Edith Bunker 
Edith Hunker would embrace the 
Equal Hights Amendment "ii it were explained to her." says Jean 
Stapleton, the actress who plays the subm issive and slightly I laky female lead rd the television co­ medy “ All In The Fam ily." 
"She would leap to it." Miss 
Stapleton told the Washington Press 
Club. "She is the very soul of jus­ tice." 
M iss Stapleton said she w ants the 
E d ith Bunkers of America to sup­ 

 port the EHA. rejected by the North 
Carolina Legislature this week. 
“ We can t be discouraged." she said. “ You just have to move on it harder 
M iss Stapleton, who has been crusading for the EH \ for two 
Nears, said she hopes a series of state conferences on women will generate new support for the KHA. which has been ratified by 35 states and needs approval bv three more bv March 21. 1979

Retiring U .S . A m b assad o r Anne 
Armstrong laughs after looking at a scrapbook presented to her by the 
London Embassy staff to mark her year as a diplomat. Thursday was her last day. 

Joan 
Little is disciplined 

Joan Utile, acquitted in 1975 fur murdering her jailer, has been disciplined fur disobeying orders at the state women’s prison af Ra­ leigh. N.C., where she is serving time for breaking and entering. 
“ She was charged with failing to obey an order and with failing to perform her assigned duties.” said prison administrator Louis Powell. 
“ A disciplinary panel found her guilty and has given her extra work duty as a result." 
Miss Little. '23. who entered prison in January* I MTH to serve a 
7-lo-Hl year sentence, was eligible to participate in a work release pro­ gram but bad not yet been assigned to job outside the prison. 
Powell said the incident, which occurred on a yard detail, was not serious enough to keep her out of the work release program. 
Miss Little persuaded a jury at lier widely publicized trial that she fatally stabbed a jailer during an escape to avoid a sexual assault. 
Fashion critics criticized 

"Frankly, my dear. I couldn't give a . . ." was Margaret Tru­ deau’s reply when asked about cri­ ticism by American fashion de­ signers of tin* short dress she wore to a formal White House dinner. 
"Look. I inst don’t care what the 
American designers thought." said the 'JS-year-old wife of Prime Min­ ister 
Pierre 
Flliott 
Trudeau. 

"What I wear is nobody’s business bul my own." 

The question came at a Montreal fashion show organized by Tru­ deau's Liberal party. She was wearing one of the dresses that was said to have shocked the American experts, a tight-fitting, below-the* knee sequined sheath. 
Amin continues bloody purge o f Christians 

NAIROBI. Kenya (A P I — Refugees from Uganda claimed on Thursday that President Mi Anim is continuing a bloody purge of Christian tribes iii bis troubled Fast African country. 
Kenyan church sources in touch with 
American missionaries in Uganda, however, said they have received no reports of Americans being molested and that missionaries there appear determined to remain in the country aud continue their work. 
Other missionaries, they said. are wailing in neighboring Kenya for a suitable time to go to Uganda. 
Killings 
The sources stressed that indepen­ dent confirmation of refugee reports is difficult to obtain and there is no ac­ curate estimate of the number of per­ sons killed. 
Reports reaching Nairobi from refugees recently arrived from Uganda said Amin s purge of Acholi and Langi tribesmen and other Christians in­ volved widespread killings and a r­ rests. 
A spokesman for the Roman Catholic 
Holy Cross Order, which has 35 Aliter* lean missionaries in Uganda, said iii 
Nairobi: 
" I speak to them (the missionaries) every day. They are iii very good spirits and are alt slaying in Uganda, 
Nobody has pressed the panic button yet." 
Several have relumed to the country ill the past few days. lie said. 
In another development Thursday , a 
K tin an newspaper quoting We s t 
Oerman intelligence sources said a spectacular hijack was to have been staged at I camia s Kntebbe Airport to coincide with an expulsion of Amer­ ican nationals from Uganda. The report was discounted abroad. 
The newspaper, the mass*circulaliun 
Daily Nation. said it had reliable in­ formation that a plane was to be provided by the Ugandans after Amin ordered the Americans to leave the 
I country during a meeting he had scheduled with them earlier this week 
Mingle 
The plane would then have been hijacked by members of the Popular 
Front for the Liberation of Palestine 
I who would have mingled with the 
Americans before boarding the a ir­ craft, the newspaper said, 
The American and West German em bassies iii Nairobi said they had no j information on the alleged hijack plan 

Howard Hughes was warden of 
!»i<; his own prison 
JL 
• The Howard Hughes mystery has 
WASHINGTON taken an ugly turn. 
The late billionaire, once a daredev il pilot and a dashing Hollywood pro­ ducer. became a living skeleton in Ins last years, a grotesque, shrunken de­ hydrated shadow of the man he had been. 
The Mexican authorities told us he died of criminal neglect. 
Now the U.S. authorities are trying to determine whether his aides en­ riched themselves while they let him languish. 
Key to mystery 

The key to the mystery is contained in the private papers that the Mexican authorities confiscated, at our instiga­ tion. from his last penthouse prison in 
Acapulco. 
We also arranged for U S. tax agents to photograph the papers in Mexico 
City. 
The papers include a fascinating daily log of the billionaire's activities. 
Ile spent his last years watching a constant round of movies. 
He alternated between his bed and a lounging chair: he nibbled his food, sometimes taking hours to complete a sparse meal. The routine was punc­ tuated by painful, often prolonged trips to the bal broom. 
It is clear from the papers that 
Hughes was both the prisoner and the warden. 
He imprisoned himself in hlacked-out penthouses from the Bahamas to Nicaragua, from Vancouver to London. 
Issued orders 

 lack j 

A 
S 
Anderson 

 report on the food content of the lead­ ing dry cereals. 
_ 
** 
He concluded in a Feb. 8. 1974. leGfcr that "they are mostly carbohydrate with a small amount of vegetable pr<^ tem. For instance But* Wheats contoid more protein than most of the cereal* yet a 15-ounce box would provide about 
45 grams of soybean protein (approxi­ mately one-half the daily maintenance requirement for a man of your size. I" 
In July. 1973. aide Levar Myier was helping Hughes to the bathroom inH V 
London penthouse. Suddenly. Hie fragile Hughes lost his footing, crusted to the bathroom floor and broke a hit). 
It was the last time he would walk 
A year later. Hughes described tile 

The fa d in g Hughes constantly sought medical advice* tv hi th he seldom heeded

Iii Bonn. a Foreign Ministry represen­ tative. noting the new paper report was allegedly based on a West German in­ telligence report, said no such report had been received by the ministry and added: 
"There seems to be a lot of wild speculation going on in Nairobi." 
Amin last week barred the Am er­ icans from leaving in apparent anger over President Carter’s statement that violations of human rights in Uganda 
“ have disgusted the entire civilized world." He later lifted the bar. 
At the same time he blocked any 
American departures from the country. Amin scheduled a meeting with all American residents. The Daily 
Nation said this meeting was to be the occasion for the expulsion which would lead to the hijacking. 
Amin lirst postponed the meeting and then called ii off completely when lie lifted the travel ban. 
The United States says there are some 24U Americans living iii Uganda, but Amin puts the figure at IOU. 
Econom y package approved 

WASHINGTON (A P ) - President 
Carter's p ro g ra m for economic stimulation passed preliminary tests 

 i i i the Senate and House on Thursday. 
First the Senate, by voice vote, aud then the House, on a '2'2ti-173 roll cull, agreed to amend the budget for the current year to allow $17 5 billion 

 i i i emergency spending and tax cuts. 
Later action will be required to ap­ prove the specific tax cuts and spend- ing programs. 
Republicans i i i both houses made clear that their vote lur the budget amendment did not commit them to support C arter’s tax-cut plan. but showed only that they see the need for some economic stimulus. 
Many Republicans favor a perman­ ent tax cut ruttier than the one-shot. t5U-per-person rebate proposed by 
Carter. 
The budget amendment accepted by both house's will raise federal spending iii the current fiscal year, which ends oil Sept. JU. to $417.5 billion That wilt mean a deficit of $89 8 billion 
The House delayed uni ll next Tues­ day consideration of Carter’s mmjified 
$l3.8-biilion plan of tax cuts, including rebates for 'JOO million Americans and a small permanent lax reduction for 45 million couples aud individuals. Plans for increasing federal spending by $3.7 billion over (lie next seven months are covered iii separate legislation 
When the tax-eut bill conies up for debate next week, an early vote is ex­ torted on a Republican effort to shelve 
Hic t arter rebate plan and substitute an $11 -tuition across-llie-lmurti |n*r- 

 i i i ai lent lax cut 
3 arrested; cocaine seized 

DALLAS IA P I — Three Dallas men were arrested and 18 ounces of high* quality cocaine confiscated by federal drug agents Wednesday night i i i a shopping center, authorities said today 

(he D LA Mid Hie men listed Dallas addresses 

He issued the orders, and they were obeyed explicitly. Some­ times the orders involved monumen­ tal. million-dollar matters. 
On Nov. 12. 1974. for instance, in­ structions went out from the penthouse to his top lieutenants. 
"lh* has a staggering plan of great importance regarding Las Vegas.’’ they were informed. 
They were ordered to be "available within 3 • 4 hours so that they can all start to work im m ediately oil Ins plan." 
This staggering idea, it turned out. was to construct a huge new Las Vegas liotel-casino complex surpassing all others iii magnificence. 
He had lust the right name for it: the 
Howard Hughes. 
Bul most of the billionaire s orders were much more mundane. 
Typical were these instructions, which he issued on Dec. 23. 1971: "His head pillow is to be inserted with the hard blue-green pillow next to his buck and the open end of the pillow case on 
Ins right (not the left as Indore). Also. larry the pillow by the bottom seam." 
Ills doctors provided him with drugs, which they warned were harmful. These nostrums, apparently. gave him Ins only release from Ins confinement. 
His lust conscious act. according to witnesses, was a feeble, pathetic at­ tempt to inject a hypodermic needle into his shriveled arm. He filially dropped the syringe helplessly. 
Medical advice 

Vet the fading Hughes constantly sought medical advice, which he sel­ dom heeded His doctors urged him to exercise, to regulate his activities, to cat more nourishing food. He never did 
In early 1974. he wanted to coniine 
Ins intake lo prepared cereals. 
"Please.’’ In* scrawled i i i his own handwriting, "have them research the serial (sic! field — either in F reeport. 
Miami, or LA . before I consume any more of that . . . meat. But psi* (sic! exercise all caution toward security." 
One of the four doctors who unended him. Dr. Norman Crane, produced a 

 surgery in his own handwriting. 
Walter Robinson, a distinguished Low* don surgeon, "performed a most diffi­ cult piece of surgery on my left lew which was broken ai the hip . . wrole Hit* bedridden billionaire. 
"T h e surgery involved driving*** steel spike right thru the bone constitute a joint and major structure of my leg at that point. 
"This surgery was performed ut tin 
London clinic, and I was under coffle plete anesthetic for 4 hours . . . I wrfv transported from the London Clime lo my present position in the Bahamas on a stretcher iii un ambulance and by plane accompanied by un expert and fully qualified doctor every inch of the way. 
"T h e point is I did not leave the stretcher anil prone position from time of surgery until arrived in Freeport until I was put in a bed, and I have not left that bcd up until and including this moment — not even going to the bath­ room.*’ 
No exercise 

Both doctors and aides tried to per­ suade Hughes to exercise and get back on Ins feet. But lie just lay in bed and dreamed of Ins past deeds. 
For a final moment, he resolved lo fly again. Hi* inquired whether Dr 
Hughes, whom he remembered from the past. would examine him for his pilot s license. 
/ 
Aide Nadine Henley reported fin 
March 12. 1975: "D r Hughes is healthy and is still one of the FAA medical examiners Ile will come down here to examine von for your license but tu­ bas said lie will not comr down milles you arc up and around and walking M 
The billionaire wanted to know lp)$ much advance notice the doctor would need 
Back came the reply: ''IJT. 
Hughes said he would require yppW£ 
I mutely two weeks notiee before cnu* mg down to Freeport to interview you." 
OI course, the former aviation I Mr rn never flew again; he never got otic of bed His doctors simply watched htm atrophy, and they seemed helpless to prevent it

S.A. groceries still cost less 

SA N A N TO N IO EXPRESS— Friday March 4 1977 
H 

EXPRESS CAPITOL BUREAU 
Al STIX — San Antonio's grocery prices remained the lowest in the state through February, according to the state agriculture department s latest market basket survey. l ite monthly survey shows the aver­ age price of 2o food items in the Alamo 
City was SIS.5o, compared with a statewide average of $19.4o. 
Although the prices in San Antonio wore nearly $2 less than the highest average found in McAllen ($2o.42). cost for food continued to increase. It went up 19 cents from .January. 
Shoppers in San Antonio paid $18.37 for the same 2o commodities in Jan- 

But f o o d prices increased 19 cents since Jan u ary in the A la m o City 

 nary. the survey shows. 
Over the last six months the average price on the grocery items has gone up 
SI.24. 
Agriculture Commissioner John 
White urged consumers to continue shopping around for good quality food at the lowest cost. 
“ They should especially be looking for Texas-produced commodities." he 

 said. 
Among the 2o items showing prices increases, the biggest increase w as for coffee, up IO cents from January. 
Coffee was selling for $3.o8 a pound when the survey was made in F e ­ bruary. 
Prices also increased slightly on eggs, American cheese, chicken, tuna, apples, corn flakes, tomatoes and or­ 

 ange juice. 
Milk prices have remained the same even though dairymen's cash receipts are decreasing monthly. White said. 
The survey also showed the price for some beef products had dropped slightly. 
The rank of Texas cities surveyed and their average food prices are as follows: 
San Antonio. 818.51); Laredo. $18.95; 
Austin, $18.97; Tyler. $19.22: El Paso, 
$19.3o; Abilene. $19.5o; Ft. Worth. 
$19.58; Corpus Christi. $19.68: Lubbock. 
$19.68; 
Also. Houston. $19.73; Dallas, $19.78, and McAllen. $2o.42.

Similar legislation bas been filed for

The Alliance for a Better 
City is getting ready to give the town another lesson in how not to play politico. 
Word is out that ABC has decided lo back a political unknown. Robert 
G. Rodrigue/, against Councilman 
Henry Cisneros in the District I race. 
Anybody with a smidgen of poli­ tical insight knows that Cisneros is unbeatable in Ins near West Side stomping grounds. 
Cisneros 
Of course, nobody has ever ac­ cused A B C of acting smart. And what political sense members have is clouded by their intense dislike for Cisneros, who has refused to enter the establishment group’s fold. 
‘■You can ’t be around (A BC ty pes) 3o minutes before the subject of Henry Cisneros comes up." says one i ommunity insider. 
“ They want to know: Does he 
Ii.ive a (political) weakness? And: 
How eau we stop him ?" 
So instead of using their re­ sources te* influence races where they have a chance for success. ABC members are going bt throw their money at the District I race and hope to knock off Cisneros. 
It must be nice to be so wealthy. 
COPS loses 
COPS may already be wishing it hadn t backed single-member dis­ tricting in the Jan 15. City Charter revision election. 
The organization’s leaders went to City Hall Thursday to try to slop the council trom approving an out- of-court settlem ent <d its suit against Oscar W yatt's Coastal 
Sla te s empire 

They came up two votes short. 
The only city duds who sided with them were Henry Cisneros, Al 
Rohde and Richard Teniente. 
Those three councilmen are run­ ning for re-election in West and 
South 
Side d istricts where 
Communities Organized for Public 
Service is a political heavyweight. 
So they voted the COPS line. 

With the exception of Mayor Lila 
Cockrell, who is running at-large. the other council members are in districts where COPS has little in­ fluence. 
So they simply ignored the liis- trotiies and threats at Pity Council meeting anil voted for the settle­ ment. 
That wouldn’t have happened if the councilmen were facing at-large 

 campaigns where COPS could use its political muscle against them. 
Prior to the City Charter rev ision election, this writer predicted that 
(O P S was taking a rope to its own hanging by supporting the single­ member districting plan 
Thursday, the council used that rope and left (O P S twisting slowly in the wind.

The KSAT-TY. Chunnel 12, news department caught C S. Rep. Henry 
B. Gonzalez iii a bear trap of his own making Wednesday night. 
During a report on the congress­ man’s resignation from the House 
Select 
Committee on 
Assassi­ nations, newsman 
Rick 
Lozano showed a recent film interview during which Gonzalez indicated that even the suggestion of resign­ ing Extended him. 
In tin* interview. H ie- congressman 

 w a s asked about the resignation option. 
“ Why should I resign ?" he re­ sponded emotionally. “ I'm seeking an aeeEUUilability on funds.” 
At that point a reporter off-ca- meru said something inaudible, and 
Gonzalez said angrily: 
"That's not the point. You’re in­ terring (that I might resign) by raising tin* issue. 
“ All I'm telling you is that would be a strange reversal of what a public official ought to be doing.” 
Apparently, somewhere along the way, the congressman decided that such a reversal wouldn't be too strange after all. 
See the melodrama grows more interesting.

Tareyton goes low-tar one better. 
Of course 
Tarry ton’s filter reduces tar... 

Tireyton has less tar than 
IVA of all other cigarettes sold! 
...but it also improves the taste with activated charcoal. 

The U.S. Environmental Protection 

Agency recently reported that charcoal is the best available method for filtering wa­ ter. As a matter of fact, many cities across the United States have instituted charcoal filtration systems for their drinking water supplies. The evidence is mounting that activated charcoal does indeed improve the taste of drinking water. 
Charcoal also helps freshen air in sub­ marines and spacecraft. 
And charcoal is used / f.T to mellow the 
I i taste of the t 

 finest bourbons. Vi

Senate okays reorganization 

NEW YOUK TIMES SERVICE 
WASHINGTON - Without op­ position and with little debate, the Senate approved legislation 
T h u rs d a y th a t would give 
P r e s id e n t C a rte r the broad authority he wants to reorganize the government. 
The measure would permit the Pre­ sident to create, consolidate or reshape federal agencies or shift agencies from one department to another as long as the Senate or House did not vote to block his plans within HO days of the time they are proposed. 
At a hearing on the other side of the 
Capitol Tuesday, Rep. Jack Brooks, chairm an of the Government O pera­ tions C o m m itte e , and a few other re p re se n ta tiv e s and legal sch o lars raised doubts about the constitutiona­ lity of the legislative veto device that is the keystone of the legislation. 
Unanimous 
But the m atter was not even m en­ tioned in the b rie f S enate d eb ate 
Thursday afternoon. The bill was ap­ proved by a vote of 93 to (I. 
Despite the opposition of Brooks, 
D-Tex.. and a few of his allies, there appears to be overwhelming support in the House for legislation similar to that passed by the Senate Thursday. Those who have been following the bill close­ ly said it was likely the reorganization authority would become law before 
Easter. 
Between 1949 and 1973. every presi­ dent was granted the authority Carter asked for. 
Nixon denied 
After the Watergate scandal broke, however. Congress, wary of potential a b u ses of pow er by the e x ecu tiv e branch, refused to renew P resident 
Nixon s reorganization authority. P re­ sident Ford never asked that it be reinstated 
The Senate added a few limitations to the sweeping power that 
Carter sought. 
• The hill would give the President the authority to reorganize the b ur­ eaucracy for three years, instead of the four years he asked for. 
• It would require each proposal to deal with only one logically consistent subject matter to prevent submisisions that covered a wide range of govern­ ment aetiv ides. 
• It denied the President the auth- only to make changes in regulatory agencies. 
At C arter’s request, the Senate did not include the restriction applied to 

 previous Presidents that they submit no more than one reorganization plan every 3o days. But Bert Lance, direc­ tor. of the Office of Management and 
Budget, gave the Senate formal assur­ ance the a d m in istra tio n would not swamp Congress with more proposals than it could reasonably handle at one time. 
The bill would give the President the right to amend his plans within 3o days of the time they went to Congress. It also included procedures that would guarantee a vote on any reorganization proposal on which there was signifi­ cant opposition. 
The purpose of the latter provision was to make sure no agencies were restructured simply because the pre­ sidential proposal was bottled up in a congressional com m ittee or filibus­ tered into effect. 
The m ea su re would not give the 
President the authority to create new 
Cabinet departments or abolish exist­ ing ones. Such actions would have to go through the ordinary-legislative pro­ cess. 
New plan on pardon to vets eyed 

WASHINGTON (AP) - The Carter a d m in istra tio n is co n sid e rin g im ­ pro v em en ts in less-thun-honorable d isc h a rg e s for som e c a te g o rie s of 
Victnam-era veterans rather than con­ sidering such cases individually. 
Robert Lipshutz. counsel to P r e ­ sident C a rte r, said T h u rsd a y “ no definitive decision has been reached’* but.that the White House is working on this with the Defense Department. 
Lipshutz said such an action would be taken only for those given adm inis­ trative discharges and would not in­ clude those given d ish o n o rab le di- eharges requ iring m ilita ry cou rts- martial action. 
As possible examples, he mentioned veterans discharged for m a riju a n a sm oking or veteran s who d e se rte d after serving honorably in Vietnam. 
When (’arter announced his pardon for about HI.IKM! draft evaders, lie said he was turning over to the Pentagon the question of deserters and others iii the military who received less-than- honorable discharges.

S A N A N T O N IO EXPRESS— Friday March 4 1977 
Carter to test political gambit 

W A S H IN G T O N POST SERVICE 
WASHINGTON - President Carter stands to gain a lot at relatively little risk from his first “ Ask President 
Carter” radio call-in show, scheduled from I to 3 p.m. Saturday over the CBS 
Radio Network. lf p u b lic reaction is fa v o ra b le . 
Carter will have a whole new technique for taking his case, whatever it may be at the moment, directly to the people, a gambit his close friend and adviser 
Charles Kirbo thinks he will have to use in some of his projected battles with Congrese. 
Not even Franklin D. Roosevelt, the last President who mastered radio as a m eans of explaining his policies, could claim that his “ fireside chats” were part of “ a continuing effort to make himself available to the people of the country to answer their questions” as the Carter White House has done. 
And no other president has had a mechanism to claim that any citizen. 

 no matter what status, can pick up a telephone and have the sam e toll-free chance as any other citizen of reaching the President. 
The fact that the chance is incredibly sm all — p e rh ap s m illion s of phone calls have to be funneled down to a single speaker in the Oval Office — m ay not d etract from the sym bolic openness of the event. 
The test will be whether the public likes the idea. 
“ Our concern is more breaking dow n the isolation of the President than an­ yth in g e l s e , ” s a y s B a r r y J a g o d a , 
Carter’s television consultant 
. . The volume of calls that we receive is not as significant as the fact that millions of people will lie able to hear those calls that actually do get into the Oval Office.” 
The risk to Carter’s im age is mini­ mal because in six weeks as President, he has shown himself very much at home with use of the electronic media. 

He came across as relaxed, confident and determ ined during his fireside chat and both of his televised news conferences. 
A sid e from so m e u n fo reseen presidential fum ble with d isa stro u s policy implications, the wbrst likely to happen is that the questions, which will not be screened in advance, turn out to be inane, or repetitive, or both. 
Moderator Walter Cronkite, there to clarify confusing questions and keep people from ra m b lin g on too long, might be reduced to an endless series of pleas to “ turn your radio down.” if callers are confused by the standard 
7-second delay. 
The White House anticipated that. 
“ Our assumption is that there may be those in this country who would be disrespectful to the President, but that no one would lie disrespectful to Mr. 
C ron kite,” said White House P r e ss 
Secretary Jody Powell. 
Ile didn’t say what the White House 

 would do if millions of callers became an g ry or f r u s t r a t e d b e c a u s e they couldn’t get through. 
No claim s 
The W hite H ou se is m a k in g no claim s the callers w ill represent some average slice of America. 
Ja g o d a said Carter will be able to answer only 3o to 5o calls at best dur­ ing the 12o minutes of air time. 
A sked w hat the P re sid e n t m igh t learn from this experim ent. Ja g o d a talked about “ . . . the immediacy of the q u e stio n s and the p a ssio n and the emotion involved in som ething that electronic com m unications som ehow, are able to convey better than seeing it on a piece of paper.” 
The mechanics of the call-in, while quite sophisticated, were not difficult for the American Telephone and Tele­ graph Co., which says there is virtually no ch an ce of all those phone c a lls jam m ing equipment in Washington. 
5 indicted for GI fraud 

W A S H IN G T O N p o s t SERVICE 
WASHINGTON - Five 
Florida promoters were in dicted for c r im in a l fraud by a federal grand jury in Miami Thursday. 
In 1974 the promoters co n v in ced re ce n tly r e p a tr ia te d 
U .S. prisoners of the Vietna­ mese war to invest their back and disability com ­ p en satio n in various schemes. 
The indictment, which was unsealed in Miami, stated that the POWS and other investors lost about 
84 million in sch e m e s that ranged from hydro­ ponic farm ing to m oder­ nizing old DC3 airplanes. 
D uring a 1974 court hearing of a civil suit brought by the Securities and E xchan ge C o m m is­ sio n , a fe d e ra l ju d g e b ra n d ed the s c h e m e s 
“ horrible, vicious, b ru ­ tal. and diabolical." 
At those hearings, it was revealed that one 
T h o m a s P re sto n sen t 
“ welcome hom e” letters to ab out SI) ex-PO W s claiming he had been a 
POW during the Korean conflict and had lost back pay in bad investments after the war. 
Preston offered expert investment advice. 
Preston, who is serving ll) years in Texas on a state court conv iction for defrauding POWs there, was not nam ed in the federal indictment. 
Robert J. Allen, who is se r v in g five y e a r s in 
Texas for the fraudlent s a le s to 
PO W s, w as named in the indictment. 
O th ers n am e d w ere 
Howard VV. A lexander, 
Charles J. Diaz, Ja n ie s 

VV. Brewer and I. Vasi- lios. 
A cco rdin g to the in ­ dictment, the defendants established Alexander & 
Allen, Inc*., which sold industrial revenue bonds purportedly to finance several projects. 
But the in d ictm e n t charges that the princi­ pals pocketed most of the money. 
W ORLD TRADE CENTER tow ers, center foreground 
Lawsuit claims 11o-story towers causing windstorms 

ASSO CIATED PRESS 
NEW YORK - Can the twin 
11o-story World Trade Center towers, 
New York City’s tallest buildings, cause windstorms? 

The owners of a 34-story office building nearby think so, and they’re suing the trade center in state 
Supreme Court for dam ages “ in the millions.” 
They claim the shiny m etal-and-glass towers create 45 to HO mile-an-hour winds that cause their building to creak and sway. 
The suit against the Port Authority of New York and New Je rse y contends, “ Winds blowing from a westerly direction through the a p e r t u r e " between the 1.35o-foot towers are “ greatly increased in velocity, thereby causing unusual, increased and unnatural wind pressures” on the sm aller building 
The result is “ abnormal rotating and swaying m ovements.’* the suit says. 
At the National Weather Service, a spokesman said tile phenomenon of increased wind speed is calk'd a “ venturi effect." 
“ When you’re pushing the sam e volume of air through a sm aller sp ace” sim ilar to the opening between the two towers, the “ wind gains in veloci­ ty," he said. 

The suit isn ’t the first com plaint against me towers. 
Television viewers maintain the buildings cause 
“ gh osts" that disrupt reception for miles around. 
But that problem should be remedied when broad­ 

 casters move transm itters from the Em pire State 
Building in midtown to the trade center, m aybe later this year. 
The Port Authority, owner of the trade center, said in response to the wind suit that the owners of the building at 22 Cortland St. should have been sware of the wind conditions before construction of the sm aller building began in 19(19. Construction of the first trade center tower began in 19HB and the building was “ topped out” in 19711. The second tower reached full height in 1971. 

The buildings are the second tallest in the world, outdone by Chicago’s 1.45o-foot-tall Sears Tower. 
The suit against the Port Aurhority m ay be the first time in recent years that one landlord has sued another for alleged wind dam age. 
According to an official of Victor o. Schinnerer & 
Co,, the underwriting m an ager for Continental 
Casualty Co. which writes insurance for architects, most claim s against architects concern glass blown from buildings by extreme wind or temperature. 

Wind tests conducted 

The suit w as filed by tile M etropolitan Life 
Insurance Co. and by real estate men Harry B. 
Helmsley and David M. Baldwin. 
Baldwin says wind tests conducted by C anada’s 
University of Western Ontario concluded the Cort­ land Street building was structurally sound but the towers were causing “ a condition that normally wouldn’t 'occur,” requiring more than SI million in structural reinforcements.

SAN A N T O N IO EXPRESS— Friday March 4 1977 

A column rises over the legendary Super­ stition M ountains east of Phoenix, re­ calling Indian smoke signals of bygone days. In this case, though, a jet passed overhead, leaving behind a white vapor trail. — AP W irephoto 
Moon church eying Texas 

HOUSTON (A P ) - A member of the Nev 
Sun 
Myung Moon s I ’nifUa- turn Church said Thurs­ day the church now feels it is time to focus atten­ tion on states like Texas 
P a tric k H ickey, tin' 
Houston leader for the church, said the move into Texas’ largest city is part of a move into southwestern states to broaden an earlier focus that had centered on the 
East and West coasts. 
Hickey said there now are 22 m embers of the church in Houston and that KU more will be here later this spring to help expand the alteration. 

Houston religious leaders last Decem ber condemned the Moon church and said they were glad it had not made much headway iii tin1 area. 
Among them were M i­ chael G. Kapp. area dir­ ector of the A m erican 
.Jewish Committee. 
“ Considering the anti- 
Semitic undergirding* of so much of the teachings of tlie Moon church. I am concerned their presence will be a divisive factor iii the positive relations which exist between the 
•Jewish and non-Jew ish community in Houston." 
Kapp said Thursday. 
Man waving bottle shot by detective 

Police said an off-duty robbery d etective s e r­ iously wounded a San 
\ntonio man Thursday after the man advanced toward him brandishing a glass bottle. 
The man was shot only after being warned sev­ eral times bv the lion- uniformed officer to drop the little , police report­ ed 
The victim, identified bv police as Prank \ as­ kile/, ail, of Kl.» K. G ray­ son St., was listed iii ser­ ious condition with a gunshot wound to the upper right chest late 
Thursday. 
Casque/ was booked by proxy for simple assault on a police officer and assault with intent to commit bodily injury in connection with an alter- i at ion with another man.

Children’s hospital bill advances 

EXPRESS CAPITOl BUREAU 
AUSTIN — A House subcommittee 
Thursday approved a $3.2 m illion con­ struction budget to ensure a state hospital for retarded children in San Antonio, Rep. 
Frank Madia announced. 
Madia, who sits on the Health and Welfare sub­ committee that recommends spending for mental health and retardation programs, said the funds would go to renovating six buildings on the grounds of San Antonio Chest Hospital. It is expected the project will be completed by next March. 
Along with the construction money, the subcom­ mit tee approved a $5.7 million two-year operating budget for the school. 
Faces more study 
AU recommendations of the subcommittee must be approved by the full committee and then by the 
House Appropriations Committee. 
The subcommittee also approved an additional two-year $4o(1,(HIO appropriation needed for the chest hospital to keep its food service operation. 
In other action related to San Antonio, the subcommittee: 
• Rejected a requested $o5o,ooo appropriation for the San Antonio State Hospital to provide space for additional beds. 
Granted a two-year $5oo,ooo appropriation to the state hospital for its non-residential service program. The hospital had requested $7oo,ooo. 
• Adopted a resolution by Madia recommending state hospital superintendents no longer be allowed to receive fringe benefits on top of their regular salaries. 
Adopted another Madia resolution to require the 
Department of Mental Health/Mental Retardation to begin submitting budgets for each of its centers in the state. 
Madia said overall, the state hospital complex in 
San Antonio has been recommended for the majority of funds requested. 
Vote OKs m assage parlor bill 

By ROBERT OCHOA 

EXPRESS CAPITOl BUREAU 
AUSTIN — A bill allowing counties to regulate massage parlor operations received tentative ap­ proval Thursday in the Texas House. 
The vote was 115 to 5. 
AU Kl members of the Bexar County delegation who were present voted for passage of the bill which will gel a third and final reading Monday. 
11B34 By Rep. Gene Green of Houston allows counties to regulate licensing, health standards, inspection, advertising content and clothing stan­ dards of massage parlors. 
License 
It also allows the county to revoke a parlor’s li­ cense upon conviction of any penal code offense and to prohibit massages of a person of the opposite sex. 
Although he voted for passage, Rep. Matt Garcia of San Antonio said he is still not satisfied with the legislation. 
He said the measure is open-ended and leaves room for parlor operators to circumvent the real intent of such legislation — to stop the massage business altogether. i think a bill should get to the point, be exact, anticipating all ramifications,” he said. 
One provision i i i the bill would prevent parlors from charging customers specifically for a massage. 
In Garcia’s v iew, “ they could charge the customers for other purposes and make the massage a freebie.” 
Suggestion 

’i f we passel a bill which stall'd no person shall lay a hand on another even for therapeutic purposes, then you'd stop all the massage parlors.” he said. 
Opponents of Green's bill were able to derail the bill temporarily Wednesday But it was maneuvered back onto the calendar Thursday where it was moved up to third reading with a minimum of de bate. 
Two Bexar legislators. Reps. Toe Hernandez anc 
Abe Ribak. were on excused absence and did no! vote.

44 killed in Italian cadet plane crash 

PISA. Italy (A P ) — An Italian air Giusto Airport in this central Italian force C13o transport plane taking naval city. cadets on their first training flight 
Officials said the plane apparently crashed into the mountains north of exploded as it hit the mountain at an here Thursday, killing all 38 cadets altitude of about 2.8oo feet. and the and six crewmen, the Defense Ministry wreckage caught fire. Bodies were sajd spread over a half-mile range. 
The giant plane, carrying first-year cadets of ihe Leghorn Naval Academy, 
The flight was sch^ jlJ‘(i r to ^ 
Italy's Annapolis, crashed against MI. hour. over Tuscany and the Tyrrhenian 
. Serra shortly alter takeoff from San .Sea. before returning to I (sa.

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Fridoy Morch 4 I 977 

D e c is io n a p p la u d e d 

HOUSTON (A P ) — San Antonio 
City Council s vote to settle out of court “ probably is the first real major step” toward settlement, a 
Lo-Vaca Gathering Co. official said 
Thursday 
Don E. New quist. Lo-Vaca vice president for public affairs, added: 
“ San Antonio has been a real leader in the overall settlement. 
“ I think their taking an official step probably will furnish motiva- 

 tion to go ahead. 
“ There are numerous other customers involved, and I think the vote, hopefully, will give some mo­ tivation to go on in a timely way with the other boards and governing bodies considering the matter. 

“ Hopefully this is a step toward getting some reconciliation to a problem that is not benefitting anyone. 
OUT-OF-COURT 

Continued from Page l.\ 

 prices. However proper settlement will prevent rates from escalating as ra­ pidly as in the past.” Pyndus said. 
In a third and related resolution, council endorsed .San Antonio as head­ quarters for a new company that will 
I** created if the settlement is finally carried through. 
Attached to that resolution is a letter from the president of Lo-Vaca to Tom 
Berg. chairman of City Public Service board, saving he feels sure the decision will be to locate here. The settlement proposal lists San Antonio and Corpus 
Christi as alternate sites. 
Rohde abstained <o1 the voice vote approval of the headquarters resolu­ tion. He said he simply wants to be consistent with opposition to the over­ all settlement 
The settlement resolution authorizes 
CPS to proceed with the settlement proposal. CPS is the publicly owned utility that actually filed the breach of contract suit against Lo-Vaca. Coastal and Coastal's bourd chairman. Oscar 
S. Wyatt. 
Other customers 
Settlement still depends on accep­ tance by other major customers such as Austin. Lower Colorado River 
Authority. Corpus Christi and Central 
Power and Light plus major private industrial customers. 
A target date of June 3(1 has been arbitrarily set for closing. But it is not binding. 
In addition to approval by other cities and industries, which have been waiting on San Antonio to make the first move, the settlement must be ap­ proved by various government agencies and bv Coastal officers and stockholders. 
During debate on the issue. Mrs. 
Gallegos recited a list of state actions she believes is necessary to relieve the pressure on soaring utility costs. 
“ The state re fu se s to do anything alinit this critical situation, and it is time our elected officials exerted their leadership in pushing the state to do something." she said. 

' SEMI-ANNUAL 
FamousMaJkers 

WE'VE 681 IHE MOST POPULAR 
NATIONAL BRAND APPLIANCES 
THAT ARE NOTTO OE MISSED 
Because... 
We want to be your favorite i 
"W store oolco 

( O PS had been promised earlier council would try to get key state offi­ cials here for a public meeting. 
Mayor Cockrell said she, C PS 
Chairman Berg and others have been in touch with state officials. While their schedules won't permit them to come here, they will receive a delega­ tion in Austin, the mayor said. 
“ We will go there bv the bus loads.” commented COPS member Clare Etta 
\\ illiams. 
In discussing what he termed “ the frustrations of the issue,” Hartman said the price of gas is not going down, but it has nothing to do with the settlement itself. 
CPS attorney 
The attorney hired by CPS to handle the lawsuit and settlement. W illiam 
Miller of W ashington, urged council to 
“ make the decision today or forget the settlement . . . negotiations can't go on indefinitely.” 
The rate relief package pushed by 
Cisneros would be funded by diverting current city income from the 11.5 per cent of total CPS revenues it receives iii lieu of takes and from reinstating the 78 cents per month charge now rebated to customers on the first 3oo kilowatt hours of electricity burned each month. 
The resolution committing council to a plan by the end of March embraces these concepts. 
In addition to council s own rate re­ lief package, all customers will share in cash benefits from the overall settlement with Coastal/Lo-Vaca. 
Rebate 

These benefits w ill be applied against the fuel adjustment clause on monthly bills and shown as a rebate. 
The overall settlement would create a new company to replace Lo-Vaca. remove it from Coastal and establish a customer benefit trust from a stock transfer. 
C oastal would finance a gas search program under which newly discov­ ered gas would be sold to the new company at discounted prices. 
AQUIFER 

 t ontinued from Page l.\ 
Kinney and Comal counties. 
Thursday's hearing, however. evolved i nto a debate between the 
Edwards Task Force. Bexar Coun­ ty and the attorney general's office on the one hand, and Uvalde Countv on the other. 
Bexar County Judge Blair Reeves spoke on behalf of the task force w hich is comprised of representatives I rom 
San Antonio. SARA, the Edwards Un­ derground Water District. Bexar. Co­ mal. Kendall and Medina Counties 
Judge Reeves told the board “ the change to seven different orders is ri­ diculous iii our thinking 
Speaking for the Edw ards Task 
Force. Reeves said “ in the past I :I months we have testified al three pub­ lic hearings and. counting today, two 
Imard meetings to support the reten­ tion of a single Edwards Order. 
“ In each case. the I ask Force was unanimous i i i l l s decision. And. I might note the great majority of testi­ mony at the public hearings was iii agreement with our position. 
“ This.” he said. "should be ade­ quate evidence we consider it vital to our local interests to maintain one strong Edwards Board Order to pro- ted the single recharge zone that spans seven counties. 
Webb told the board the seven county proposal is factually detective. 
"That is.” Webb continued, "aquifer knows no political boundary, I here- lore. treating people differently , based solely upon county boundaries, is ar­ bitrary aud capricious. 
“ There being no rational basis in having seven different orders with dif­ ferent prov isious to control pollution of one body of water, the proposal be I ore you toda.v would be. iii my opinion, indefensible in any legal attack that might be made upon it 
However, it was Uvalde County 
Judge Leo Dailey who captured lip* limelight with his testimony 
Feels sorry 
Parley, who touched on pollution. 
Imiitics and sympathy for the people ut san Antonio, told the hoard “ we re not mad at san Antonio. We lust feel sorry for them." 
Parley told the board long before mere was an Edwards Order, "the cit­ izens of 
Uvalde 
County pledged 
14oo.(IOO of their own bond money to building dams to protect the Edwards aquifer. 
“ What have we done to contaminate the Edwards aquifer''- Parley asked 
“ We haven't done anything to conta­ minate it. All we've done is built three dams which just recharge the aquifer. 

 and 15 recharge stations, that's what we've done. 
"W e recharge millions of gallons of water for those people in San Antonio 
We don't mind them having it — we lust want to use a little of it as it flows by us.” 
Then. without naming names. P a r­ ley launched a barrage at Webb. 
“ Then there's that boy from the at­ torney general's office.” he said. 
"Every time San Antonio shows up there s someone from the attorney general s office right behind them. It makes you wonder where the legal ef­ fort ends and the politics starts,” 
Parley charged 
Switching t>aek to San Antonio, the 
Uvalde County judge said. "those peo­ ple use this waler on their river to run little boats up and down . . . they use it on their grass and on their golf courses. Why they even brew beer with it. 
"In San Antonio they have fusses and fights, they have COPS (Communities 
Organized for Public Service). Those things don't concern us, aud we don't want to be part of them. 
"There s no question but what the proper procedure would be separate orders.” Parley concluded 
Nugent testifies 
State Rep. Jim Nugent of Kerrville, iii whose district I valde County is lo­ cated, also testified for the separate order proposal. 
Nugent not only supported the plan, but took a swat at Bexar County legis­ lators who has a bill pending in the 
House t*» revamp the TWQB. 
Not naming names. Nugent asked the board to "give our testimony the same weight you would to those San 
Antonio representatives who have filed a bill to ’blackjack* this board." 
(State Rep. Ron Bird of San Antonio, is author of a bill now in the House calling for the reorganization of the 
TU QU.) 
Also testifying for the proposal was 
Uvalde Mayor Cradles N. Cain, and 
John VV White, executive director of the Nueces River Authority headquar­ tered iii Uvalde. 
Alleged slayer 

A l.B L g U t H g lt : (A P ) - District 
Court Judge Richard Traub Thursday ordered a man accused of killing an 
Amarillo restaurant manager be re­ turned to Texas to face a m urder charge. 
Traub gave public defender Alice ll til or 24 hours to ask the New Mexico 
Supreme Court or federal court a stay of the order transferring David G rijal­ va, 21, of Gallup. 

O SKALO O SA low i 
(A P) — Postmaster Lee 
Hart may have an addi­ tion to the credo about nothing interfering with a postman’s appointed rounds 

Clarence Gibson, 7b, was driv mg out of the post office parking lot 
Wednesday when he lost control oi his ear The 

VII in the day's mail 

 vehicle smashed into the front window of tile post office. The ear finally came to rest i i i the mall sorting room after it had skidded through the lobby, destroying 15o post boxes and slightly injuring one customer 

It wasn't business as usual afterwards, said 
Postmaster Lee Hart

23o escape paying tax 

WASHINGTON (AP) — A total of 23o of Hic nation's wealthiest individuals paid no federal income taxes in 1975. the T reasury D epartm ent reported 
Thursday. But the agency predicted that number will shrink substantially for 197(i. 

In a special an alysis o rd ered by 
Congress, Treasury said 34.121 in­ dividuals reported adjusted gross in­ comes of $29o,99o or more but 239 paid no tax. 
The total represented a decrease from the* 244 who paid no tax in 1974 but an increase from the 1B4 
A SSA SSIN A TIO N S 

Continued from Page IA he wanted to talk to Gonzalez before that happens. 
Gonzalez called Sprague an “ un­ conscionable scoundrel** in his letter of resignation Wednesday and said he had no choice hut to resign, since 
House leaders were not supporting his efforts to fire Sprague. 
O'Neill also said the fate of the committee ma\ hinge on whether three witnesses can provide new information on the King murder. 
Committee mem liers were talking 
Tlmrsda> of either dropping the Ken­ nedy investigation or delaying it while proceeding with the King probe. 
O'Neill said. 
O'Neill said the three witnesses, who were not identified, have ev idence that 

 would be of keen interest to the 
American people. 
The witnesses have not previously been called. O'Neill said, because of the committee's internal problems. 
Gonzalez fired Sprague Feb. 19. prim arily for refusing to cut staff costs. But the o th er c o m m itte e members countermanded the order, saving the firing had to be done by the full committee. 

House D em o c ratic le a d e r Jim 
Wright and U.S. Hep. Richardson 
P re y e r, c o m m ittee m e m b e r, said 
Thursday the committee would meet 
Monday, whether or nut Gonzalez was present. 
The committee is scheduled to end. bv House order, on March 31. 

 who escaped taxation in 1973. 
However, when expressed as a per­ centage of all individuals in that in­ come bracket, the proportion of non- taxpayers has remained virtually con­ stant'for the three-year period, the department said. 
The Treasury report concluded that despite the ability of some wealthy individuals to escape taxation, “ most high income taxpayers pay very sub­ stantial amounts of tax and are subject to high effective tax rates.'' 
The report said the effective tax rate for both taxpayers and nontaxpayers combined in the $299.999-plus category was 42.9 per cent in 1975. Less than 15 per cent of those taxpayers had tax rates of less than 29 per cent. Treasury said. 
By comparison, a family of four with the median income of $13,719 for 1975 would have had an effective tax rate of 
19 per cent, assuming the family took the standard deduction. 

T reasury concluded “ the changes made by the l ax Reform Act of 197H will largely elim inate high incom e nontaxables.” 

HAYES 

III said the government did not object to the exam in atio n and noted that 
Hayes had been declared competent before standing trial in state court for the shooting. 
Hayes was convicted in July by a state court jury of aggravated assault and he was sentenced to two to IO years iii prison. 
Attorney’s request 
H a y e s’ atto rn ey , M arvin M iller, stated in his motion requesting the psychiatric exam ination that he was told by a Texas Department of Correc­ tions physician that H ayes suffers from Organic Brain Syndrome. 
“ The disease is progressive and not curable." Miller said. 
Judge Spears gave Miller and his associate. William P. Miller, 2o days to file pretrial motions in the case and gave federal prosecutors 2o days to respond. 
Miller also asked Judge Spears to allow Hayes to stay in Wilford Hall until the examination because he was encountering pro blem s from other prisoners in Bexar County Jail. 
“ They have been cussing at him and kicking at his do o r,"-Miller said. 
Judge Spears told U.S. Marshals to insure Hayes is not disturbed in the jail even if it means separating him from the other prisoners. 
No disturbances 
Both Marvin and William Miller told 
Judge Spears they will probably file motions attacking the composition of the grand jury, charging selective prosecution and double jeopardy and asking for a change of venue. 
Pinckney said prosecution of the case will be led by Dan Rinzel. deputy cinel of the criminal section of the U.S. 
Justice Departm ent Civil Rights Di­ vision. 
Rinzel presented the Hayes case to the federal grand jury here last month.

PITTSBURGH (AP) - A Pittsburgh man has been conv icted on mail fraud charges for engaging in a national real estate sales b usin ess th a t listed properties, but rarely sold them. 
D R. M aclean was found g u ilty 
Wednesday following a six-week trial in U.S. District Court. Federal prose­ cutors contended his venture netted 
$899.9(19 in fees over a six-month pe­ riod.

Very little salvagable items are left of the John Reynolds home in Velma, Okla. A tornado ripped through the area late Wednesday night, destroying everything in its path. Five homes were totally destroyed. Three tornadoes were reported in the area. — AP Wirephoto 
Bill cutting I T HSC surety fee near law 

EXPRESS CAPITO!. BURDEAU 
AUSTIN — A bill saving the University of 
Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio some SI.”) million in medical malpractice insurance premiums was sent to the gover­ nor Thursday. 
Simi ate Bill 191. In Sen Kent Hance of Lubbock. pa SMM I the House Thursday morn in u b\ a unani­ mous 125-o vote. 
SB391 allows the I niversity of Texas and Texas 
A&M University systems to establish a separate seif-insuranee fund to pay any damages against a member of the medical staff or student. 
Estim ated saving 

According to the bill s House sponsor. Hep. Tom 
I ber of Buy < ity. the bill will saw the L l system an estimated $5 million when it s next medical mal­ practice insurance premium comes due April I 

The I T Health Science Center at San Antonio paid a premium of $7oo,ooo for its current policy. 
According to Hep. Don Cartwright of San Antonio, tin* school had been advised its renewal premium might run as high as $1.5 million when it comes due 
April I 
In speaking for the bill Thursday. I ller told House members claims against the I T system for the past five years had never exceeded Slot).OOO annually. 
Based on the estimated premium for the next year. I her said “ that’s a lot of premimum to pay for no more claims than have been collected ” 
Cartwright, who has a similar bill in House com­ mittee, said he would amend Ins proposed legisla­ tion to include the Baylor University Medical and 
Dental schools, the Texas Tech Medical School and the School of Osteopathic Medicine in Fort Worth. 
None of these are included in the Hance- Cher measure passed Thursday. 
The entire Bexar County House delegation voted for S Iiiioi

If the U niversity of 
T e x a s at Sun Antonio is forced to live with Gov. 
Dolph Briscoe’s recom­ mended budget cuts. the student-teacher rat in will increase and the teachers will have less time for students. 
That was the belief Dr. 
B everly Gibbs. C TS A vice president for academ ic affairs, ex­ pressed Thursday. 
More than 25o con­ cerned students crowded into a UTSA lecture room to attend an information­ al meeting on the effects on the university of pro­ posed budget cuts. 
The meeting was or­ ganized bv the Coalition for the Maintenance of 
Educational Funding, a newly formed student group. lf the worst does hap­ pen and the governor’s reeonimendat ion is ap- proved, the university lias a difficult tusk ahead, said Dr. Gibbs 
The number of courses the university is able to offer will decline, sin* said. < Jraduate course of­ ferings will have to be narrowed and electives will have to bi’ tightly controlled. 
Legislators 
Dr. Gibbs said, how - ever, tins may not come to pass. Dr. Peter Flaw ti, 
UTSA president, and other members of the administration are work­ ing diligently w itll the 
Texas legislators, she said. 
The v ice president said she believed pressure by students or faculty is premature at this time.

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Friday March 4 1977 
Rescuers get closer to imprisoned miner 

T O W ER C IT Y . 
Pa 
(A P ) — Workers using hand tools chipped i ii - gerlv at a *5o-font-thirk coal seam Thursday to rescue a miner trapped alone in a tiny chamber deep underground for more than two days. 
There was no word "ii seven men still missing in the mine. Two bodies had been recovered. 
While the men worked. 
Ronald Adley. who at­ tracted rescuers by rap­ ping on the walls of his small prison nearly a 

 mile back from the mine's entrance, waited with a supply of chewing tobacco and food pushed to him through a tiny shaft bored through the coal and rock 
Wants chew 

“ (five me a chew ," 
Adley had asked when rescuers finally made contact late Wednesday through the six-inch communications hole. Ile also asked for a shot of whisky, but was sent orange juice instead 

Ad lev's tapping was heard by rescue workers at 4:5o p.m. Wednesday. nearly 32 hours after a mass of water crashed through the roof of a shaft where the men were working in the 
Rocher Coal Co. mine. 
Asked about rumors that other noises had been heard inside the mine, federal mining of­ ficial John Shutuck re­ plied 
“ W e’ve heard some reports but we haven't confirmed them.

 and outside of our own people, we haven't been able to (>Kk up any other sounds.” 
Adley told his rescuers that lie was alone. Walter 
Vicinelly, the state's top mining official, said, ad­ ding that, at most, the seven missing miners could not be more than 
25o feet away in a funnel adjacent to Adley’s rocky cubicle. 
Voice contact with Ad- 
Icy was made at 7:45 p.m. 
Officials said there was plenty of air in the mine pocket where Adley was trapped. They said the temperature was between 45 and 5o de­ grees. 
“ Adley is talking to us.” Vicinelly said at a 
Thursday news briefing. 
“ He's asking how far we’re in 
He's sitting there waiting for us to get to him.” 
Shutuck. an official with the federal Mining 
Enforcement and Safety 
Administration, said Ad­ ley was perched on splintered timber resting on a 45-degree slope in an area four-by-six-bv-eiglit feet. 
Good spirits 
“ The man is in excel­ lent sp irits,” Sh ut ack told a news briefing. 
Shutack said rescuers were perforating the coal face with a series of small holes, then cutting out the coal between Hid holes with hand tools rather than machinery to lessen the danger of a cavein. 
The mine is in Penn­ sylvania’s major anth­ racite. or hard coal. region, about 4(1 miles northeast of Harrisburg. 
A state mining inspec­ tor said Thursday that the arca being mined was dangerous because of water trapped in aban­ doned mine shafts, but he said that compared to other mines in the state it was relatively safe. 
Adley’s sister, C’arol 
K riser, stood watch behind a rope, staring at the mouth of the mine. 
“ W e’ve been here all night and we’re going to stay until he comes out." sin* said. 
His wife and two chil­ dren waited at home. 
State muling inspector 
Clarence E. M iller last visited the mine Jan IS 
In an interview Thurs­ day, lie said the arca was dangerous because of ii neharted. abandoned mines where water could be trapped But he said this was common, adding that it was impossible to stop mining in uncharted areas 
“ You would have to just shut anthracite down and forget about mining altogether.” he said. 
Police official killed 

(T U .W A N . 
Mexico 
(A P) — Ten men arilled witll automatic assault rifles attacked the car of an assistant chief of police, killing him and wounding a bodyguard, the police said Thursday. 
Culiaean, the center of illegal heroin trade in 
Mexico, has bet'll the site of dozens of shoot-outs between rival drug gangs and between the gangs and the police and sol­ diers, 
The victim of Wednes­ day s slaying was Alfredo 
Keyes Cureil, 49. assis­ tant chief of the state ot 
Sinaloa’s investigative 
I whee force, (uliacan is near the P acific coast and about NM) miles south of the U S. border. 
Bodyguard 

Keyes and his bodyguard were on the way to Keyes’ office when a van truck pulled iii front of the car, the van’s rear doors were thrown open and at least IU men with what the driver identified as I .S.-made commercial AK la au­ tomatic rifles opened fire on the car. said the chief of Sinaloa’s investigative police, Marco Antonio 
( amarena. 
The car was tut by more than (Hi bullets. 
Kcvt*s was hit ‘JU times iii the body and two tunes iii the head 
Keyes had m ade a name for him self iii the last two years within the police department by fir­ ing anti drug agents who w ere su sp ected of dealing with the u n d er­ world. 

Japanese trio frees hostages 

M IN E R S w a it to ta k e their turns in tfhe a r o u n d - t h e - c lo c k e f f o r t s to reach trap p e d m iner 
IO years given in kidnap 

S N Y D E R (A P ) - A 
19-year-old man con­ demned to death from 
San Angelo was sen­ tenced to ten years in prison Thursday for an­ other conviction — ag­ gravator! kidnaping in tile abduction of a state trooper. 

A nine-man. three- woman jury deliberated three hours in Snyder district court before agreeing on the penalty for 
Charles 
Francis 
Rumbaugh. 

On 
Wednesday, the 
132nd district court jury found Rumbaugh guilty of kidnaping police of­ ficer Keith Plie rigo on 
Dec. 7. 1975. 

TOKYO (A P ) — Four 
Japanese nationalists armed with a samurai sword and guns surren­ dered early Frid ay, ll hours after seizing hos­ tages in the headquarters of Japan’s most powerful economic organization. 
None of the captives was harmed. 
Police said the men handed over their weapons at about 3 a.m. and emerged one by one, wearing headbands with the rising sun emblem, from the 14-story head­ quarters of Keidanren. a federation of 898 busi­ nesses and industries. 
They bowed deeply to police and said: “ We are sorry to have bothered you." 
The rightists had scat­ tered leaflets denouncing big business for “ poison­ ing" Ja p a n ’s postwar society and landscape and they cited Hie Lock­ heed payoff scandal as one example. But beyond drawing attention to their 

 cause the purpose of their siege was not immediately clear. 
The men were taken to a nearby police station for questioning. 
The armed men sur­ rendered after talking for more than three hours with the widow of Yukio 
M ishim a, the noted 
Japanese writer who had championed a return to ancient Japanese values. 
The writer had figured prominently in the group’s leaflets. 
Mishim a committed ritual suicide in 197o after he failed to incite an uprising among Japan’s self-defense forces, lie had led a small private army of die-hard nation­ alists called the Shield 
Society, and at least some of the gunmen were believed to be former members. 
One of the conditions the men laid down in talking to Mrs. Mishima was that they be treated as samurai. Japanese 

 warriors, not as crimin­ als. police said. 
The siege began short­ ly after noon Thursday when the four men en­ tered the 
Keidanren headquarters, near the 
Im perial 
Palace, carrying the sword, a ri­ fle and a handgun. Firing three shots, they seized about a dozen hostages, but quickly all but four were released.. 

About five hours later, with hundreds of police blanketing the area, they freed two more. 
One of those set free. 
Tetsuya 
Senga, a 
87-year-old managing director of the federa­ tion, said the four were 
“ considerate, served us tea and allowed us to call our fam ilies to inform them we were in no danger.’’ 
Iii their leaflets, the men said they were members of the “ Youth 
League to Crush the Y and P System.”

San Antonio's efforts to block legislative fund cuts.

A quifer gets com petition from Canyon 

Canyon Lake water, if taken from the right place, is of better quality for municipal use than water from the Edwards aquifer, studies show. 
Dr. Herbert Hannan of 
Southwest Texas State 
University in San Marcos explained the results of studies by himself and students at the Texas 
Water 
C o nservation 
Assn., m eeting al the 
Hilton Palacio del Rio 
Hotel. 
Dr. Hannan said the 
Dost plate to draw water from Canyon Lake is near the surface next to the dam. 
He and SWTSU s t u ­ dents have tested water quality at checkpoints lo­ cated on the Guadalupe 
River, around the reser­ voir and d o w n s tr e a m from the dam. 
Reservoir

San Antonio Express 
EDITORIALS 

Charles O . Kilpatrick 
Editor and Publisher 

W illiam J Reddell 
G eorge Carmack 
Fane L. Burt 
Editor of Editorial Page 
Associate Editor 
M anaging Editor 
Gas settlem ent vote no surprise 

City Council, in a B-3 vote, moved the complex and contro­ versial settlem ent proposal between Coastal States Gas 
Corp. and 4oo customers a step nearer resolution. 
Approval by council was in­ evitable. Tough political reality switched only one vote — that of 
Councilman Henry Cisneros — when voting time came. 
Council had informally com­ mitted itself to settlement last summer if a proposal could be improved to what council members referred to as a “ bot­ tom line proposal.” It was gen­ erally conceded the bottom line had been reached by negotia­ tors. 
San Antonio approval is one of a series that must be forth­ coming before the proposal may go before 
District 
.Judge 
Charles Matthews in Austin and the Railroad Commission. The 
City of Austin had scant opposi­ tion to the package at a public 

 hearing last week. The Lower 
Colorado River Authority has a committee at work among 
LCRA customers to see how they view the proposal. 
Most of the negotiators agree the settlement proposal is better than pressing for bankruptcy of the Coastal States empire be­ cause it spins off for settling customers a new company in position to supply gas. A gas supply under settled conditions is presumed to be a desirable goal. San Antonio, for example, is to receive approximately $84 million in benefits — stock, discounted gas and earnings from stock in new company. 
That payout could be larger if the gas search program which is part of the package is more successful than estimates made for settling purposes. 
Risks on each side are real. 
Realism suggests risks on the side of settling are less than in bankruptcy. 
House knuckles under to pass a tougher code o f ethics 

The U. S. House of Repre­ sentatives passed a code of eth­ ics bill Wednesday after seven hours of debate. On a roll call, the measure goes to the Senate by an overwhelming 4o2 to 22 vote. The Senate is considering a similar bill. 

The bill is the second part of a proposal by the commission on federal pay, which supported congressional aud other pay in­ creases IF Congress would bind itself to a credible code of con­ duct. The speaker insisted upon passage in a strong form. 

If the Senate passes the bill, members of Congress w ill be li­ mited to outside earnings of 
$8,B25 a year. The bill requires extensive financial reporting, prohibits acceptance of gifts va­ lued at more than $1oo, and prohibits junkets by lume-duck members. 
The income restriction aims at ending the spreading practice of paying fat fees for members to speak outside Congress. 

Basis of the code, aside from the salary commission pressure for it, is a series of opinion sur­ veys showing public confidence in Congress at a low ebb. Opin­ ions fed on abuses of office and lax response by Congress. 
Unquestionably, the public expects a higher code of conduct than has been tolerated — if not, in fact, encouraged 
— by the members, themselves. Polls show, generally, that a member’s constituents usually rank him high but the Congress low. Reform-minded members were incensed, however, when 
Florida’s Rep. Robert L. F. 
Sikes was re-elected just after the House reprimanded him for abuse of power as a committee chairman. 
If members have to make a sacrifice by limiting earned in­ come. so be it. They all volun­ teered. But few of us would consider a job paving $57,5oo and perquisites much of a sacrifice, especially for anyone likely to want to be in Congress. 
D etoxification a useful step 

Uncle Sam will build a de­ toxification center for Bexar 
County. The Economic Develop­ ment Administration grant of 
$425,ooo will fund a 52-bed alco­ hol detoxification building to house drunk persons who would otherwise normally be put in jail. 
The special housing, which could be ready within a half year, was announced this week by 
County 
Com. 
Tom 
Stolhandske, chairman of com­ mittee handling the problem. 
The place will help eliminate problems of crowding in jail and of putting drunks and other ill persons in cells. The County 

‘Well, well, well! What have we here?’ 

Mental Health/Mental Retarda­ tion organization will provide professional staff in the unit. 

Stolhandske’s goal is to have judges process drunks through the unit into treatment facilities. 
Traffic from drunken persons is steadily rising and it is obvious that the jail isn’t designed or staffed to handle the problem. 

Next step is to get regional jails, with farming space, w here all prisoners can be given phy­ sical exercise while they are in­ carcerated. The number of per­ sons in jails is supposed to in­ crease with time and more courts. 

Letter likened to a snow job. 

Sir: Heading Robert Paul Sieurello's letter (Feb. 2o) was like sitting in a courtroom, listening to a mouthpiece expound. It is difficult to dispute his chosen words; still you know i f s a snow job. 
Buried in all the verbiage was the fact that the national Republican can­ didates won in 1952 and again in 19o8 
Then he tries to tie those \ (d o ries to 
Ins own ideas of how the Am erican m ental process should function. 
Anyone with enough m ental ability to tie his shoelaces knows that Ike won the election of 1952, and not the DOP. 
Ike could have run on the Dirty Dishes in the Sink ticket and won. 
The 19G8 election was decided in the 
New H am pshire p rim ary , and LIU. 
Twilight zone 

Speed of news 

Sir: Bud new s tra v e ls fast, w hile good news barely sees the light of day. 
The F ed eral C om m unications Com ­ m ission announced last week th at a lcnghty investigation of the Bell Sys­ tem showed that Bell is providing good service at reaso n ab le rate s and that 
Western Electric should not be sep ar­ ated from the Bell System. 
The story w arranted one paragraph in the Express, 
Sunday s E x p re ss-N ew s e a r n e d a lengthy story beneath a lour-colum n headline, quoting an obscure book that claim s American Telephone and Tele­ graph is becom ing a g re a te r risk to investors. 
T h e book, w ritte n by an o b s c u re lawyer and an even m ore obscure en­ gineer, sells for $75o per copy. Wow! 
Well, at least they a d m it th e re is s o m e r is k in v o lv ed in 
AT&T inv estm en t, which is why AT&T d e ­ serves a reasonable re tu rn on its in- vestm ent, which totals $73 billion. 
That investm ent alone is indicative that AT&T is here to stay. 
Marco (William 
News Services Manager 
Southwestern Bell Telephone Co. 

Som e rights m ust yield to society 

Sir: Thank you for including in your 
Feb. 19 editorial, that portion under the heading “ A way to get the weeds cu t.” For 1. too, have sought as you have to get our city officials m ore attentive toward this effort to reduce the eyesores so prevalent in our city. 
You m ay be interested in the a t­ tached com m ents I received in 1975, in response to a letter to Mayor Cockrell concerning this subject. 
I believe there is a limit on how far we can extend the rights and freedom of ownership privileges, if we want to provide ourselves a well preserv ed com m unity, free of owner dereliction that exposes our com m unity to the hazards of health, fire, and crim inal progression. 
Perhaps one day we will recognize that we cannot live together without relinquishing portions of our unaliena­ ble civil rights in order to benefit the wholesomeness ol society. 
Harold ll. Graham 
(NOTE: Attachment was a letter from the director. Metropolitan Health 
District, which said compliance with law and lack of specific state law makes it impractical for the city to try to force elean-up of private property.)

Mrs. O’H air, church are called alike 

Sir:- Mrs. Madalyn M urray O 'H air 
(Express. Feb. 19) is a worthy ad v e r­ sary of Christianity. She is as absolute and aggressive, as overbearing, a rro ­ gant and intolerant, and as dogm atic, om niscient, infallible and salvific as any of the churches have ever been. 
She and such a brand of Christianity deserve one another. 
When Mrs. O’Hair says she knows m ore than anyone else about church corruption, she sounds like any all­ know ing c le rg y m a n ; but su re ly so ­ 

 meone with such a lovely sm ile (inter­ view photo) has to have at least the tip of hor tongue in cheek. Still, I’ve seen bishops sm ile that way, too. 

Mrs. O’Hair m akes it clear she is not an atheist, but an agnostic hum anist. I respect her “ ignorance” and m ine, too 
— in fact, w e’re all in a “ w ilderness” 
(was any church ever m o re condes­ cending than she when she prom ises with a sm ile to lead Christians out of th eir guilty confusion?) — but she sounds as dogm atic and alm ost defiant in her protestation of agnostic ignor­ ance as som e C hristians professing their theistic convictions. Do we have som ething in com m on here? Like be­ ing proud of our hum ility? 

We may have even m ore in common: scandal. The scandal of dogm a which is a s tu m b lin g block to ag n o s tic s tripped up by the difference between not being able to know anything and being unable to know everything, and the scandal of the com m and to love which is a burden to the churches as they try to flesh out their theism by ea stin g out fea r, p rid e, p re ju d ice, trium phalism and force of any kind — except tho force of exam ple. Madalyn 
M urray O’H air m ay be right in finding the scriptures “ incredible” when they call for that kind of love, and in some m easure she m ay be justified in criti­ cizin g c h u r c h e s w h ich s o m e tim e s preach better than they practice such a scandalous com m and. 
Fr. Sherrill Smith 

Lopez 
Portillo has job of reform 

PUERTO V A L L A R T A , M e x i ­ co — This ha- to be paradise. 

The sea glows like a sunlit turquoise 
T h e c o b b l e s ! oned to wn b e s u n ­ spoiled, even bv th< delirious tourists. in th e cro o k ed art)): b f t h e Si n a 
Madre. 
Almost everybody I a: 
> ■ k u i the place virtually sings with prosperity. 
Yet, even here, the corrosive prob­ lems that are gnaw ing at all of Mexico are enragingly present. 
Recently, for instance, the people of 
Puerto Vallarta voted decisively for a mayoral candidate of a party in oppo­ sition to the PR I, the single “ revolu­ tionary” party that has ruled Mexico since the 191o revolution. 

Machine gesture 

T h e g o v e r n m e n t iii M ex ico City didn’t like this at all and, with a g es­ ture as old and as delicate as that of the Chicago m achine's, ca m e in and carted off the ballot boxes. 
But the people, like so m any groups all over Mexico today, were not cowed. 
They barricaded the downtown and 

Little saga o f little Puerto 
Vallarta represents many things that are happening in Mexico today. 

 kept th e so ld iers at bay for se v e ra l days. 
F inally, th e P R I did w in, at least tem porarily. 
Its m ayor was installed, but with the whispered prom ise to the people that he would soon be replaced. 
This little saga of little P uerto Yol- larta represents m any things that are happening in Mexico today. 
T h e p r o g n o s is fo r th e f u tu r e , if things do not change ra th e r radically under the new p resid en t. Jo se Lopez 
Portillo, is not good. 

In between 

As o n e p r o m in e n t 
M e x ica n new spaper editor puts it, despairingly, 
"M exico is going to end up som ew here between Puerto Rico and A rgentina.” 
W hat he m e a n s is s o m e w h e r e b etw e e n th e d e p e n d e n c e upon th e 
United States that is already here and growing (7o per cent of exports go to the United States) and the utterly sen­ seless v iolence of Argentina, an arch is­ tic in ch aracter and intractable in so­ lution. 
Unfortunately, this rings all loo true in this beautiful land, as it e n te rs a new and dangerous period. 
For years. Mexico has prided itself iii being one of those countries that was taking a "th ird way*’ — and the recent p re s id e n t. Luis F e h e v e r riu , p rid e d himself on this to the point of m ania. 
This third way, som ew here ideologi­ cally betw een c a p ita lis m an d c o m ­ m unism , was to use discrim inatingly the best of both and avoid the worst of both. 

Worked well 

This w orked well, until co rru p tio n itself becam e the m ain reason for po­ litics. 
Now, the new "th ird w ay,” which is happening here and m o re and m o re across th e world is th at Mexico h as b e c o m e one of th o s e c o u n t r i e s too s tro n g to fall to ta lly to C o m m u n is t subversion or sen seless violence but too weak to reform or revitalize itself. lf not a r r e s te d in s o m e d r a m a tic way. what this new “ third w ay” m ean s is slow but certain political and econo* 

Li en the organized gu er­ rilla movements hare noir lost their ideological char­ acter anil have broken dona into warring bandit gangs.

WASHINGTON 
— 
Haul 
Warnke is adroitly walking Ii is way through minefields and. to hear his defenders tell it, on water,

(SALT) and head of the U S A rm s

(At DA), 
So far, every battle of the Warlike cam paign has gone his way 
He h as been r e c o m m e n d e d for confirm ation by tin* Senate Foreign 
Relations Com mittee.

Theodore Roosevelt.

Wendell Holmes.

Hill. his Oyster Bay estate, in 1912.

Must find it

Personal traits

American scene is devoid of them. Sen.
