American hero.” 
Cleland won the Silver S ta r , the 
Bronze Star and the Soldier's Medal in 
Vietnam. 

Extravagant praise 

As other senators chimed in with tilt* e x t r a v a g a n t p r a i s e ol I le land that m arks the rhetoric of that form. ( le­ land took it in good grace Hearing all that. In* said. “ I would he well advised to let my ease rest here."

VA functions iii other departm ents or the entire agency into the Department of Health. Education and Welfare. 
Other goals

24. 1942. an d grew up in n e a r b y 
L ith o n ia, lit* r e c e i v e d th e A tla n ta

Army duty

1965 in the Signal Corps. He qualified as a paratrooper the following vear and was an aide to the com m anding gen­ era l of th e s i g n a l c e n t e r at F o rt 
Monmouth. N J.

Vietnam and was only five weeks from com pleting his tour iii 196K when he was wounded.

RAY MARSHALL new labor secretary 

19 7 7 
4oo U.S. mercenaries fighting in Rhodesia 

JO H A N N E S B U R G , South A frica 
< \P) — About 1,2oo foreigners, 4oo of 
I lem Am ericans, have joined the 
Rhodesian arVnv in its war against black nationalist guerrillas. 
These men, also from Britain, Aus* tralia, Portugal. South Africa and 
Canada and several other European countries, are largely leftovers from conflicts elsewhere in Africa, Vietnam ami Northern Ireland 
Most are in their 2os or early 3os. 
Some couldn’t find jobs when they re­ turned home from other wars. Most gravitated to Rhodesia as one of the few places today where a man can es­ cape the boredom of civilian living by putting his life on the line. 
The Rhodesian government is reluc­ tant to talk about the foreigners in its 
o,ooo-man army and is annoyed by any reference to them as m ercenaries. 
Technically, the men are immigrants who happen to join the armed forces of 

Technically, the men are im m igrants who happen to join the firmed forces o f the white minority re­ gim e 

 fan Smith’s white minority regime to fight in the escalating four-year-old guerrilla war. The usual hitch is three years. 
Rhodesian military sources insist it is not unlike immigrants joining the 
American or British armies. 
Land-locked Rhodesia is a former 
British colony of 272,ooo whites and B 4 million blacks. It unilaterally declared its independence from Britain in 19B5 to avoid sharing power with blacks, but last September Ian Smith com­ mitted his government to eventually hand over the government to the black majority. Negotiations in Geneva with black nationalists broke dow n because of differences over the makeup and 

 time span of the interim government. 
Most recruits learn of Rhodesian army opportunities by word of mouth spread among buddies from old wars. 
The government, however, does some advertising in hunting and gun magazines. 
One of the largest ads appears on the back cover of Soldier of Fortune magazine in the United States. It shows the silhouette of an infantryman running with a rifle. The caption says, 
“ .loin the Rhodesian army.” 
The Rhodesian government says it does not make promises to prospective recruits, some of whom have been disillusioned by expectations of receiving a higher ra nk than 

 previously held. 
A regular infantryman, known as a trooper, is paid about $BUo a month. A captain, depending on experience and time in service, may earn $75(1 to $9oo. 
New arrivals, most of whom reach 
Salisbury through South Africa, fill out forms noting their m ilita ry back­ ground, then are sent for training, during which they are evaluated and given a rank. 
A former American Special Forces helicopter pilot was assigned as a training instructor, while a former 
U.S. Marine captain was in itially a first lieutenant but after a year was promoted to captain. 
The foreigners are not easy to find. 
In the past month, eight foreigners deserted the arm y and fled to the neighboring blaekruled countries of 
Botswana or Zambia. One was arrested in South A frica and returned to 
Rhodesia. 

First tuna boats protesting fishing restrictions put in at San Diego, 
Calif. About 9 o of the “ independent protesters” are expected back this week. — AP Wirephoto

When you want to feel soft and sensuous V ictor C o sta brings you a perfect patio dress made of cool dotted polyester-acetate. Full gathered sleeves and skirt emphasize the generous use of material to please the eye as well as give you a gliding feeling. A matching navy and white grosgrain ribbon encircles the waist as a sash, and borders the hem. Flowing and light, so you will feel absolutely feminine Sizes 6-14, 9o.oo. This handy map shows not only the boundaries of all of the city’s IO new districts but also all of the candidates voters will find on the ballot in their own particular district on April 2. This year’s election for 
City Council will find voters voting by their district for a City Council candidate. All city residents will vote in 

 the mayoral race. The city’s first district election brought out a record number of candidates — 81. The previous record number of hopefuls was 6 2 , recorded in the I 9 7 3 election. 

Senate ponders stiffer code of ethics 

WASHINGTON (Ap) - The Senate vull have it* inning on the question of ethics nest week and is tieing asked to collie up with a code substantially stiffer than the one adopted by the ll oust*. 

The House voted 4U'J to 22 Wednesday night to require disclosure of personal finances, lim it outside income aud gills, place restraints on expenditures for travel aud do away with private office accounts, sometimes known as 
“ slush funds. 
I lie proposed Senate code contains sim ilar features plus provisions de­ signed to prevent conflicts of interest, limitations on political activity and a 

 rule, similar to one already in effect in the House, against discrim ination in employment. ll also would place m ort severe res­ trictions than the House code does on the privilege of the frank, or postage- free mailing. 
The code is expelled to be on the 
Senate floor late next week Many of its features, ineluding the rules oil poli­ tical activity, arc likely to arouse eon* trovers) and long debate. ll will Im* up to the ethics committees to formulate some legislation provid­ ing penalties for violations of the ul­ timate code. 
Both codes require extensive disclo­ sure of income and holdings. Unlike 

 the House version, the Senate code calls for periodic audits of the disclosure reports by the comptroller general. Both lim it outside earned in­ come. including speaking fees, to 15 per cent of a member’s salary. This comes to IM.H25. 

Both prohibit the acceptance of gifts aggregating more than $1oo a year from anybody with a direct interest in legislation. Both pro h ib it defeated members from traveling at public ex­ pense and liar any member from being reimbursed from more than one source for travel costs. 
Both abolish unofficial accounts set up from private contributions or cam­ 

 paign funds and supposedly used to defray office expenses not covered by official allowances. To offset this, the 
House increased the official accounts by $5,ooo per member. The proposed 
Senate code does not make such an increase but asks the Buies and Ap­ propriations committees to study the question and report within 12o da.vs. 

Under the 
House code, mass mailings sent to a “ resident” not specified by name would have to be paid for entirely from public funds and could Mot Im* sent within HO da>s of an election Iii the Senate, which already bans mailings to “ resident,” no mass mailings at all would be permitted in 

 the iwo months before an election. 
The Senate code would also prohibit use of the Senate radio and television studios during the bo days before an election aud would bar members from using the Senate’s computer to make up mailing lists of people identified by political party. 

Senators would be barred from soliciting campaign funds from em ­ ployes and employes would be barred from contributing. Employes “ sub­ stantially engaged” in campaign ac­ tivity would have to be taken off the 
Senate payroll. 
Neither a senator nor an employe making $25,(NM) a year or more would 

 be allowed to practice any profession on the side or to be an officer or bourd member of a corporation or financial institution. A fter leaving office, a member would be barred for a year 
(rom lobbying the Senate. Form er employes would be burred for a year from lobbying the senator or commit­ tee they worked on. 

Most provisions of both codes would go into effect next year. The House code, unlike the one proposed in the 
Senate, delays the lim it on outside in­ come until 1979. In both versions, the limit is restricted to earned income and would not apply to such things as dividends from stock holdings.

Storms lash Texas 

Blustery thunderstorms lashed North and Hast 
Texas Thursday, sparking tornado watches and flash flood warnings. 
A tornado watch was posted for Southeast Texas and South Central Texas and flash flood warnings were issued in Trinity. San Jacinto, and Walker 
Counties. 
The National Weather Service said there was a possibility of large hail and damaging winds. 
(lusty winds of SO to (Kl miles per hour carried the storms to the northeast, hurling heavy rain and some hail. 
The thundershower activity left two to three inches of rainfall i i i portions of Northeast Texas. 
Rockwall had the heaviest amount with 3.1)o inches. 
Mostly cloudy skies covered the central portion of the state. Skies over West Texas were dotted with high clouds. 
Am arillo recorded the Thursday low of 33. farther south and east, where cooler air had not yet penetrated, readings in the 3os and lids were com­ mon. Valley readings were i i i the 7os by early af­ ternoon. 
Forecasts cal! for reduced precipitation and clear to partly cloudy skies behind the front, which st rote bed from Shreveport, La., to Cotulla. Tex., 
Thursday afternoon. Cooler tem peratures are predicted to spread south Friday. 
The front triggered winds and dust Wednesday which damaged the wheat crop i i i the Panhandle and the hard-hitting rains which followed caused some multiple auto accidents around Amarillo. Hail up lo golf-ball size accompanied many of the thun­ derstorms.

LOS A N G ELES (A P ) — Roy Rogers is no longer singing “ Happy Trails To You" and Gene Autry has hung up his six-gun. But both men are still riding high _ one has shot a new movie, the other is riding herd on a business empire. 

The two cow boy-Ii eros of films and television are wealthy men today. Rogers is back making public appearances and enjoying a revival as “ King of the 
Cowboys.” Autry is the owner of the California 
Angels baseball team and trying to buy a pennant. 
“ I've just spent $3 million for some ballplayers,” says Autry. “ If I can’t make it with them, PU have to hock my horse.” 
Autry is H9, about 23 pounds overweight and doesn’t ride horses anymore. He runs a business empire of several television and radio stations, a hotel, two ranches and the Angels. 
Rogers is B4. lean and lives an active life at his home on the edge of the desert in Victorville. He exercises daily and loves to hunt, fish, race boats 

 and ride his motorcycle "out there with the wind and the jackrabbits." 
Both men have had long. successful marriages. 
Autry married Ina Mac Spivey in 1932. and Rogers married Dale Evans 29 years ago. 
Autry made 93 films since beginning in 1934 in 
’“ Old Santa Fe.” He has sold 49 million records. 
One-fourth of those were “ Rudolph the Red-Nosed 
Reindeer.” 
“ I was the first of the singing cowboys." he says. 
“ I'm not sure I was the best, hut when you’re first it doesn't matter. Even if everybody else is better, no one can ever be first again." 
Autry's film sidekick. Pat Buttram , says ever­ ything Autry touches makes money. He drilled oil wells that produced, bought his old mox ies for television reruns, sold records. He was making 
$99o,999 a year by 1941. 
Autry says he is through with films. “ I'm like an old ballplayer whose time has past. You’ve got to move on to something else.” 

GENE AUTRY, left, in the 193os, and, right, in his office in I 974 

Rogers is back in films. “ Mackintosh and T I." was his first film in 22 years and he says more public appearances and perhaps another film arc in the works. He and Dale Evans were grand marshals of this year's Rose Parade. 

The Roy Rogers-Dale Evans Museum at Victor­ ville is filled with their memories. There is his first pair of boots and his horse Trigger — “ the smartest horse that ever lived" — preserved in a rearing position.

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Friday March 4 1977 

R E D M A C LEASES C h airm a n B. J. “ R e d ” M cC o m b s, left, turns truck fle e t k e y s o v e r to A n th o n y M o n fre y , right, w hile Bob C lark so n , second fro m left, and Jim Guthrie look on 
Itpilmar, M onfrey sign record truck contract 

Tile largest deal in the history of 
Rcdmac Leases was consumated 
Thursday when ‘23 huge diesel deli­ very trucks were turned over to beer distributor John J. Monfrey. 
The STM).(MMI plus contract in­ cludes distinctive paint jobs for the tru c k s that will deliver Falstaff, 
Pearl. Pubs! aud ( at ta Blanca boor iii the city. 
Hedmac Chairman B J. “ Red'' 
M c C o m b s and President Jim 
< int brie turned kevs to the trucks 

 over to Monfrey and his brothers, 
P rank and Anthony Monfrey, at the distributorship. ‘2o19 S. Alamo St. 
"This is the largest lease deal in money (for Hedmac). although some have involved more individual units," Guthrie said Wednesday. 
“We lease anything with wheels 
— and even some things without wheels." he added. 
Guthrie said the lease package also included maintenance man­ agement for all the trucks. 

Americans feel economy good 

NEW VORK (A P) — Americans' confidence in the economy has not diminished in the past two months despite the severe weather, a business research organization said Thursaday. 
But fewer people plan to buy cars or big appliances than in December, the 
Conference Board said. 
“ The fact that consumers continue to be confident, despite the disruptions of the hard winter, and despite high unemployment and the recent rise in the inflation rate, is most reassuring." said Fabian Linden, director of 

 consumer economics research for the nonprofit organization. 
"This may be a sign that the econ­ omy will bloom in the spring." he said. 
The board’s statements are based on a survey of 1o.o(1o households across the country conducted for it every two months by Family Opinion Inc. of 
Toledo, Ohio. 
The latest poll found that more than 
‘29 per cent of those contacted expect business conditions to improve over the next six months, up from ‘25 per cent in December. More than ‘23 per 

 cent anticipate that more jobs will be available, up from 2o per cent. 
But 2o per cent of the families view current business conditions as "good." down from about 22 per cent two months ago. Conditions are "bad,” 23 per cent of those polled said, up from about 22 per cent. 
As for buying plans over the next half year, 8.6 per cent said they plan to 

 purchase a car. compared with the 1o.2 per cent in the previous survey who planned such a purchase. 

Some 4.3 per cent expect to buy a house, up slightly from 4.2 per cent. 
But only 26.7 per cent plan to buy a major appliance, such as a refrigera­ tor or washing machine, down from 
31.6 per cent in December.

NEW YORK (A P ) - 
Weighing good news against the bad. the stock market tipped the scales on the up side Thursday in light trading. 
The Dow Jones average of 3o industrials moved up 6.57 points to 948.64, coming back from a drop of 2.66 the previous day. 
Gainers, even with losers early in the day, came out ahead by about an 8-5 margin among 
New Vork Stock Ex ­ change-listed issues. 
Big 
Board volume reac hed Mist 17.56 million shares, not enough to sustain a rally, analysts said. 
O u tlo o k good 

‘‘You still are in the midst of a technical ral­ ly, unaccompanied by substantial volum e." said Monte Gordon of 
Dreyfus 
Corp. 
‘‘The market is just shaking the snow from its shoes. 
The cold snap is over and the near-term outlook is improving." 
During the day Trea­ sury Secretary Michael 
Blumenthal tried to reassure the business community is as con­ cerned about inflation as unemployment. 
"The market is react­ ing well to the comfort­ ing words of the govern­ ment." Gordon said. 

"Bu t it still has to re­ solve longterm problems of inflation and spending. 
" It certainly is not coming forward with any great buying — it's just a relaxation of selling pressure." 
Later, the Commerce 
Department reported that factory orders fell 
2.1 per cent in January, their biggest drop since 
March 1975. The weather problems affected the dip. 
Analysts had been con­ cerned during the day that the nation s money supply would take a big jump forward and possi­ bly cause the Federal 
Reserve to tighten up its monetary policies. 

But in the latest weekly figures, released after the market close, the Fed reported the basic money supply fell by $1 billion. 
The Standard & Poor’s index of 4oo industrial stocks picked up .57 to 
112.29, and 
S & P ’s 
5oo-stock composite in­ dex rose .49 to 1oo.88. 

Car sales up 

New car sales rose 2.4 per cent during Fe­ bruary, and the four major auto makers closed higher. General 
Motors was up :ih h' 71' 4;

Logan, reporting an increase in its quarterly dividend and a 5 per cent stock dividend, was % higher to 14^g. 
Teleprompter said it received permission from the Federal Com­ munications Commission to construct a new kind of cable television antenna to receive satellite sig­ nals. 
Some oil stocks traded actively.

Continental Oil was the volume leader, down :<4 to 34>2. Gulf Oil was up

Blumenthal restates stand 

NEW VORK (AIM - 
Treasury Secretary Mi­ chael Blumenthal tried to reassure the business community Thursday that the Carter adminis­ tration is as concerned about inflation as unem­ ployment. 
And be reiterated his intention to withhold a 
$255 million loan re­ quested by New Vork Ci­ ty to pay its bill next week uniess he is con­ vinced the money tan be 

 repaid. 
"’President Carter is not a spender, far front it." Blumenthal told a luncheon gathering of business leaders. 
"He firmly believes in the need for a vigorous attack on inflation, and he sees this need as just as important as the at­ tack on unemployment. 
"As for myself. I as­ sure you that I did not take ibis job to partici­ pate in an administration

 that fails to address itself vigorously to the danger 
•if inflation.” 
Blumenthal said the administration will not attack inflation with wage and price controls, 
"jawboning" or schemes to have government noti­ fied in advance of wage or price increases. 
Instead, lie said, the administration will exa­ mine the inflationary impact of all federal ac­ 

 tivity, including regula­ tions, cost-plus purchas­ ing contracts, and re­ quirements for reports by businesses. 
In addition, the admin­ istration will seek a po­ licy on international trade that protects in­ dustry and workers hurt by cheap imports, but 
“ in ways which do not result in inflationary price increases borne by the consumer.” 

Blumenthal and Presi­ dent Carter both have suggested that New Vork 
City must solve long­ term financial problems before the administration will make short-term loans like the $255 million now requested. 
One long-term problem is an agreement, now be­ ing sought, between banks and unions on how­ to repay nearly $1 billion worth of city notes. 

N LHB rules against firm 

Handy Andy Inc. Thursday was no­ tified the National Labor Relations 
Board had overruled the grocery store chain's objection to a 1974 election certifying Teamsters Local 657. 

Handy Andy had filed objections to a 
June 14. 1974, secretballot certification election won by the Teamsters, 1o8 votes to 66. 

The company objected that the union was disqualified for certification as the bargaining representative for exclud­ ing from membership individuals on the basis of race. alienage or national origin and failed to represent employes fairly. 

The bourd overruled the employer's 

 objection and certified Local 657. 

In a blanket ruling, the board eli­ minated a procedure for considering contentions that a labor organization practices discrimination on the basis of race, sex or national origin before certifying the union as the bargaining agent of employes who select it. 

With this decision, the board overruled a 1974 decision establishing the requirement. 

A spokesman from Handy Andy said the company had no comment on this reversal and would not have a state­ ment on a course of action for a few days.

Home garden produc­ tion will be reviewed at a meeting at Wonderland 
Shopping City's Town 
Hall Tuesday ut 7 p.m. 
Interest in home gar­ dens has been rocketing iii recent years, and spe­ cialists of the Texas 
Agricultural Extension 
Service have been giving valuable instruction on the subject. 
Dr. 
Jerry 
Parsons. area extension vegetable specialist, will Ik* the main speaker. 
At the meeting Dr. 
Parsons will discuss 
"how t«» and what with" for better home gardens. 
During World War ll people all over the nation grew vegetables in their victory gardens. 
But surveys by the Ex­ tension Serv ice show that more Texans had gar­ dens last >eur than at any other tune in history. 
In recent years to­ matoes have been the most popular plant tor the home gardeners 
Additional interest has been created in Bexar 
County by the inclusion of a home garden di­ vision in the annual 
South Texas Vegetable 
Day Show in No\enil>er. 
Limousin sales

Texas Limousin Associa­ tion's sale at Houston brought an average price ol $2,261) per lot.

Sudden change 
George Kotzur of Ad­ kins found out again that soil conditions can change pretty quickly. 
Two weeks ago his place was boggy because 
•if the long spell of wet weather. 
Then the weather cleared, and tho winds blew on several days. 
Early this week Kotzur said the top soil was get­ ting too dry again. 
Ile has some of his land worked and ready for planting. 
Quick action 
Henry Declick said 
Wednesday his place on 
Xenic Road needed a lit­ tle ram. 

Thursday morning ; light rain was falling over most of Bexu 
County. 
Fields at the place hut been chiseled again and < light rain was needed t get rid of some of th lumps in the fields.

B y D A M I ) M c L L M O K L 
E p ile p tic s m ake de­ pendable employes — it they cvcr get the chance, a spokesman for T ram* mu aud IMacement Sci*- v ici's said Thursday 
T A I’s is a new aueney formed here to help re­ m ove b a rrie rs facing ep ilep tics seeking cm* plovm cni, according to 
B ill W ells, T ABS e m ­ ployer liaison 
■‘We re try mu to break the cycle ol unem ploy­ ment for epileptics — a 
(V ile usually hasid oil luiioruiiec and irrational fear of the neurological d is o rd e r, epilepsy 
Wells said 
"As a result, we try to m inim employers what

More often, to start out hy them what it

\m otiu the tilings cpi- tcpsv isn t, W ells said. is ii isn't a disease, it isn t contagious. It doesn t a i­ le d insurance or W ork­ m an's 
Fom pciisut iou rales and It doesn t affect the employes capability to do a good job. 
San Antonio was one of live I S. cities chosen for the 'I ABS program by lite 
National Epilepsy Foun­ dation. 
I ii addition to re c ru it­ m ent of p o ten tial e m ­ ployers ol e p ile p tic s .

H ie p r o g r a m . W e l l s s a d

Testing 
T hose enrolled in the 
TABS program receive extensive psychological and vocational testing to determ ine their jolt qua- litigations, Wells said 
**We then talk to em ­ ploy cfs aud I i v to coli- v bice t hem lo sim p ly consider our enrollees on ail eipial basis with other applicants." he said 

TABS will also pay 5o per cent of the enrollees training costs at the new job for the first month

"W e don t ask much of em ploy ers except I hat they g ive e p ile p tic s a chance.** 
TAB S offices are lo­ cated ut lh N. M aili St.. 
Suite 337. Inquiries into 
(lie program can be made by culling 235-4547. Wells said 
"< tile thing we've found is that enrollees in T ABS d on’t have a p hysical d is a b ility . ll s a social one. We hope lo correct that "

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Friday March 4 1977 

Mad scientist not so mad 

To hun* you r problem solved or a ques­ tion answ ered, write Action-Express, TAI. 
Box 2 1 7 U San A ntonio, TA 78297. 

'Saturday Night’ here? 

I just finished watching NBC’s “ Saturday Night (rn 
Sunday" featuring the Not Ready for Prim e Time 
Players at the Mardi Gras in New Orleans. 
I realize they had some problems covering some of the events live, but it occurred to me that this might get San Antonio some good publicity if the Fiesta people invited them to come to San Antonio to cover 
Fiesta. 
Has anything been done in this direction? 
What about the possibility of this sort of thing? 
Can Action-Express ask the right people? 
O. C. VV. 

ROCKPORT 
(AP) 
- 
Mad 
Scientist 
Demon­ strates Explosives. Mad 
S cientist 
C hallen g es 
Ford. Mad Scientist De­ mons! ra le s C harcoal. 
Mad Scientist Goes Solar. 
Mad Scientist Boy G en­ ius. 
The recent headlines in the local weekly n ew ­ sp ap er. Toast of the 
Coast Herald, bring vi­ sions of a w ild-haired, hunchbacked man, cack­ ling om inously and. wringing his hands. indeed. Bob Hogan is a. bit tousle-haired, but he 

 also is young strong and vibrant. In jest, the He­ rald calls him the Mad 
'Scientist but he also was dubbed the gentle brain-giant of Key Alle- 

Bob Hogan is a bit tousle-haired, but he is ti I sip is young, strong and vibrant 

 urn. 
Inventions 
One of his latest inven­ tions is an explosive that is safer than conventional explosives used in con­ struction. 
He also offered the fol­ lowing deal to then-Pre- sident Gerald Ford: lf Hogan can come up with a source of energy to 

 surpass tin1 total energy ex p en diture from all sources, and do it in such a manner that it is clear and nearly free, he will sell it to the federal governm ent for a sum equivalent to the national debt. , 
That may sound like a high price, but what he is offering could be worth 

 it—energy that cannot be used up, clean energy that will free tis and our children from fuel-con­ nected pollution p ro b ­ lems forever. 
Hogan is understanda­ bly closed-mouthed about this p a rtic u la r project but the energy machine reportedly utilizes prin­ ciples of gravity, elec­ 

 tronics and solar power. 
Sound far-fetched? 
P erh ap s. 
But C o per­ nicus. G alileo and Da 
Vinci were laughed out in their times and Hogan at least has dem onstrated an inventive mind. 
At age 12, in St. John's, 
Mo., he invented a land­ ing gear system that ul­ timately was used on the 

Douglas SB2C1 U.S. Nav y llelldiver torpedo plane. 
He also learn ed to fly airplanes at that age. lie received an official com m endation from 
President Roosevelt that now is registered al the late president’s library. 
L ast y e a r, working with less than Sat) worth of materials, Hogan said he installed , and has operating, a solar heat­ ing unit that could cut the heating costs of the aver­ age home as much as 5o per cent or more. 
The rig is no m ore 

 com plicated to install than an average attic fan. 
It is m ade m ostly of black p la stic, co p p e r tubing and a framework of light metal and works on cloudy days. 

With the energy crisis, solar power inventions w ere com m on but one difference betw een 
H ogan’s and m any others, according to the 
T oast of the C oast, is cost. E ith er everybody else is c h a rg in g too m uch, or 
Hogan is charging too little. 

(77^ - 

Yes, we can and we did. 
Davis Burnett, execu­ tive director of the Fiesta 
Commission contacted 
KMOL-TY, the local NHC affiliate about this. 
Early next week, we are informed, a joint in­ vitation from KMOl, and the Fiesta Commission will be extended to NHC 
Television and the pro­ ducers of 
“ Saturday 
Night" to originate one of the shows from San An­ tonio during Fiesta in 
April. 
Burnett seemed enth­ used about the idea of giving San Antonio and its spectacular annual 

 celebration some nation­ wide network television coverage — even if it may mean a few comical jabs at the city and its people. 
"We are going to invite them to come to a ‘really good civic celebration' in 
San Antonio.” Burnett said. 
Whether NBG and/or 
Saturday Night will ac­ cept the invitation re­ mains to be seen, but it certainly could be a boon lo San Antonio and its colorful annual Fiesta. 
We’ll keep you all in touch on any word re­ ceived back from NIU on the invitation. 

Police ticket policy 

The New York State Parkway Police on Long 
Island, in un effort to win a pay raise, began issuing a greatly increased number of traffic tickets to motorists, according to author Charles Reich in 
‘ The Greening of America." his source I icing the 
Nov. 19, I MBS. New York Times. 
A recent letter to your column expressed concern that something of this nature was going on in San 
Antonio. 
Apparently, it has happened elsewhere before. 
ANN SUTHERLAND 

Since we ran the ori­ ginal complaint from a person who asked if the police were deliberately writing false tickets here iii a backlash over the sick pay controversy, we have received a number of additional letters cit­ ing similar suspicions. 
In all instances the complaint has been that people were going a cer­ tain speed but that when they were stopped the ol- ficer said they were go­ ing much faster. In some cases, the drivers admit­ ted going over the actual speed limit, but ch a l­ lenged the officers’ alle­ gations of going a much higher speed. 
Police have denied there is any organized 
Campaign to “ punish" the citizens (or opposing unlimited sick leave pay­ ments for police and 

 firemen. 
And while Action-Ex­ press has received a number of complaints about questionable tick­ ets, there really have not been enough complaints to establish a definite pattern that would indi­ cate an organized cam­ paign or even a grudge ticket-vvriling spree by one officer. 
However, since all the complaints we have re­ ceived follow the same pattern of allegedly overstating the speed so it is more than 15 miles above the speed limit, we will continue to monitor any similar complaints. 
Anv pattern or evidence of a campaign by police officers or by a police of­ ficer will be turned over to Police Chief E. E. 
Peters for appropriate action. 

Colson defended 

Jo you really think anyone cares about some finical a sp e c ts of th e English language iii those iiltiercials run about Don Colson'’ nstead of tearing him down, why don t you praise ii for the fine job he does? Why are you alw ays 
‘intoning hun and saying what he does that is mig? 
MRS. E. 

Me have received sev­ eral letters about the last item we ran con­ cerning Colson’s use of 
“ thai'* in referring to people. 
Some of them have conic from English pro­ fessors, leachers and others who point out 
“ that” is perfectly all right to use in referring to “people." 
However, in their enth- usiasiu to defend tolson. most of his fans keep forgetting that 

Action-Express carries letters from readers and was not expressing an opinion ut its own about 
Colson’s English. We merely passed the reader’s observations about Colson’s use of 
"that" instead of "who" on to Colson via the co 
Inurn. 
We might point out the promotions containing that phrase: “ I f s the people that make the news" are still being run by t flannel 12.

S A N A N T O N IO EX PR ESS— Friday March 4 1977 
Court nixes FTC order splitting major oil firms 

The companies urged that the FTC must file an environm ental forecast. 
They warned of economic and e n v i r ­ onmental injury, “ unnecessary deple­ tion of our nation's natural resources," and possible new pollution from in­ creased fuel consumption to transport petroleum products. 
Cannel!a said. “ The court recognizes that its ruling today m a y signal an occasional decision not to prosecute antitrust violators for the sake of pre­ serving our environment. 
“ In the rare case where the FTC determines that the severity of the of­ 

 fense does not justify the environmen­ tal cost of remedying it. no doubt we all will be better off hearing the non­ com petitive effects rather than paying for competition with our natural r e ­ sources." 
The FTC order would “ restructure the petroleum industry and alter the manner in which oil. a depletable na­ tural resource, is produced, distribut­ ed and used." The court called this a 
‘major federal action significantly al- fecting the quality of the h u m a n e n ­ vironment' as that phrase is used in ... 
NEPA." 
Andrus: Pump the gas or else 

Imports said hurting 
U.S. sugar producers 

WASHINGTON (AP) - The U.S. In­ ternational Trade Commission voted 
5-1 Thursday in favor of a finding that imports of foreign sugar threaten se r­ ious h a r m to 
A m e r i c a n s u g a r producers. 
The commission made no immediate recommendation on what should be done about it. A sp o k e sm an said it would debate proposed r e m e d ie s at another meeting on March IO 
President Carter will be required to ta ke action on the c o m m i s s i o n ' s r e c o m m e n d a t i o n s w ithin OO d a y s . which could involve setting im port 

 tariffs, establishing quotas or provid­ ing so-called adjustment assistance to domestic producers and their workers. or some combination of these. 

The issue of foreign im ports arose because of concern in Congress that imports of cheaper foreign sugar could drive dom estic gro w ers out of b u s i ­ ness. Congress ordered the study by the trade commission 

Carter isn't required to accept the commission's recommended remedies, but if he does not, e ith er house of Congress could override him.

A SSO C IA TED PRESS 
NEW VORK — A federal court judge nullified Thursday a Fed­ eral Trade Commission order that would have broken up the nation’s major oil companies. 
The judge ordered the FTC to study the possible environmental impact of the order which would force the oil giants to change the system they now use to sell oil in the United States. 
Currently, the eight oil companies in the case are involved in the oil market from drilling ventures to o p e ra tin g service stations. The com m ission al­ leged oil companies are maintaining a non-competitive refining m a rke t and proposed divestiture .of some refining o p e r a t i o n s and p ip e lin e s . It a l s o reco m m en d ed formation of 111 to 13 new refining firms. 
In a decision on file here Thursday, 
U S. District Court J u d g e J o h n M. 
Cannella ordered the commission i m ­ mediately to begin complying with the 
National Environmental Policy Act by p rep a rin g an en v iro n m en ta l im p a c t study. 
Four times 
The environmental issue was pushed by Mobil Oil Corp.. Gulf Oil Corp.. 
Shell Oil Co. and Standard Oil Co. of 
California The four firm s were t a r ­ geted in the FTC complaint July 18, 
1973, along with Exxon Corp.. Texaco 
Inc.. Atlantic Richfield Co. and Stan­ dard Oil ( o. of Indiana

$5,(1oo apiece for the party treasury.

VVASHINGTON (A P ) - G ra b b i n g his first real chance to speed up nu- tu r a l g a s p r o d u c t i o n . 
I n t e r i o r 
Secretary Cecil D. Andrus told a pe­ troleum com pany T h u rs d a y to start pumping gas from newly-discovered reserves or else give up its federal offshore lease. 
He a c c o m p a n i e d this c r a c k d o w n with a general warning that he will not renew five-year offshore leases unless 

 spective donors, as the party tries to enlist m e m b e r s of an e x p a n d e d N a ­ tional Finance Council who would give or raise $5,ooo apiece. 
That s similar to the system used by past presidents of both parties, and it dramatizes the fundraising advantage of the party in the White House. 
Mondale appeared before more than 
4o persons at a T h u rs d a y lu ncheon atWashington's Madison Hotel Budget 
Director Bert Lance was at a dinner session at the sa m e hotel Wednesday night, with about HO persons on hand. 

 the companies involved agree to begin gas production as fast as possible. 
Andrus announced last Feb. 17 that he will personally review requests for lease extensions w here oil and gas production has not yet begun. 
His move Thursday came in the first case brought before him. a lease held by Aminoil Oil Co. in the Vermilion ar e a in th e Gulf of Mexico otf Lo­ uisiana 

A n d ru s re fu s e d to e x t e n d tin* e x p i r i n g le as e for six m o n t h s for further exploratory drilling; instead, he gave the company only until next 
Monday to find a drilling rig for one more exploratory well. 
And Andrus negotiated a detailed t i m e t a b l e for d e v e lo p in g an d producing gas reserves alre a d y d i s ­ covered on the lease. 
Aminoil has already drilled six wells and discovered an estimated 21 billion cubic feet of natural gas. Its lease, a l re a d y e x ten d e d 3o day s , ex p ire d 
Wednesday, but the company asked for six months more to drill a seventh well in hopes of finding another IO billion cu b ic feet of g a s before s t a r t i n g production. 
Andrus refused, insisting on a d e­ tailed plan to bring gas already dis­ covered into production bv the fall of 
1978.

Reading and writing 
San Antonio Wellesley 
College Club will present. a 
“ Readers’ and 
W riters” ’ program fea­ turing two Texas women authors at 3 p.m. Sunday in the San Pedro Play­ house. 
Shelby Hearon and Su­ zanne Morris will discuss their novels and exper­ iences as women in the field of writing. 
Tickets, which are tax deductible, are $5 and 
$2.5o for students. All proceeds benefit the 
Wellesley College Schol­ arship F’und.

Adult fairy tales 
“ Once Upon a Mat­ tress,” a modern musical fairy tale for adults will be presented F riday and 
Saturday at the F’ort Sam 
Houston Playhouse. 
Based oil the fairy tale about the princess and the pea, the show stars 
Amy 
La Presto as a wacky princess. 
The show is at 8:15 p.m. both nights. Admis­ sion is $3. 

Chinese art 
A major collection of contemporary art from the People’s Republic of 
China will open this weekend at 
Jo ske’s 
Downtown Store. 
The exhibit consists of

S A N A N T O N IO E X P R ESS — Fridoy Morch 4 1977 

FBI can’t authenticate alleged Oswald letter 

 w a s h in g t o n p o s t se rvice 

WASHINGTON — FB I investigators have been unable to establish the authenticity of a letter purportedly written by Lee Harvey Oswald to a 
Vight-wing Dallas millionaire two weeks before the murder of President 
Kennedy, reliable sources said Thurs­ day. aft i An FBI spokesman said only that a 
•copy of the letter had been received 
■ 

 and was being investigated, 

He declined further comment. 
However, other sources familiar with the probe said FB I technicians had concluded that it is not possible to determine through laboratory tests whether the letter is genuine. 
Although the investigation is contin­ uing. the sources added, the F B I is leaning toward the idea that the letter was a forgery. 

The letter, whose existence was re­ vealed by published repots a few days ago, reportedly was sent by Oswald to the late H L. Hunt, a strong backer of ultra-conservative causes, on Nov. 8, 
1983. 

It said: 
“ I would like information concern­ ing my position. I am asking only for information. I am suggesting that we discuss the matter fully before any 

 steps are taken by me or anyone else. 
Thank you.” 
A copy of the letter reportedly was sent to Penn Jones Jr ., a retired newspaper editor in Midlothian. Tex., by an unidentified source in Mexico 
City. 
In an accompanying note, the source told Jones that he had sent a copy of the letter to FB I Director Clarence M. 
Kelley in 1974 but had never received a response. 

Reliable sources said Thursday that the FBI has searched the files of its 
Washington headquarters and has found no sign that such a letter was ever received. 

The sources added that Kelley has not seen the document. 
Because the FBI has only a Xerox copy of the document, the sources said, bureau technicians concluded that it is virtually impossible to establish 

 through tests or analysis by handwrit­ ing experts whether the letter actually was written by Oswald. 
A further problem, the sources said, is that Oswald had a simple, almost child-like handwriting that would be easy for a forger to copy. iii audition, me sources added, the 
F B I's field investigation so far has tailed to turn up any additional evi­ dence of contacts between Oswald and 
Hunt. 
Cisneros says 
ABC trying to defeat him 

A shipwrecked U .S. N avy cargo transport, the G eneral Meigs, rolls with the waves of the Pacific O cean a few miles south of Neah Bay in W ashington. The ship was being towed to Puget Sound N aval Shipyard in 
Bremerton to be placed in mothballs during the winter of I 971 when it broke aw ay and washed into the 
| rocks. — AP W irephoto 
D evelopm ent o f small carriers given boost 

WASHINGTON (A P) - The White 
House decision to build no more nu­ clear-powered aircraft carriers but develop smaller carriers instead won a decisive test Thursday in the House. 
The House voted 232 to 181 to go along with the decision by former 
President Gerald R. Ford and later by 
President Carter not to build a fifth nuclear carrier but instead begin developing the smaller ship. 
The House endorsed the decision by approving a bill authorizing Carter not to spend $81.8 million Congress had previously appropriated for the nu­ clear carrier. 
The item was in a bill authorizing 
Carter not to spend a total $884 million for a variety of military and foreign programs previously appropriated by 
Two die after auto accidents 

An elderly man and a Colorado teen-ager were killed following separ­ ate traffic accidents Thursday. 
Pronounced dead at 2:1o a.m. at 
Green Hospital was Mike Castillo, 14, of Greeley, Colo. The elderly man. 
Oscar Jones, 87. of 48o Enoch Walk. was pronounced dead on arrival at 
Santa Rosa Hospital at 3:o5 p.m. 
The elderly man died after a car driven by the victim's son. Leroy Jones of the same address crashed into a telephone pole at Josephine and Live 
Oak streets Thursday afternoon, of­ ficers reported. 
EMS technicians reported the victim may have had a heart attack before the accident, police said. A medical ex­ aminer's ruling is pending in the death. 
Bexar County sheriff's deputies re­ ported the teen-ager died when a southliound car driven by his father. 
Tony Castillo. 38, crushed into the rear of a parked produce truck. 
The accident occurred alwiut I a iii. on I S. *281 just south of the Medina 
River Bridge, deputies said. 
The ten wheel truck, occupied by 
Reyes T. Saenz, 38. of San Juan near 
McAllen, was parked to the side of the road. The automobile left no skid marks prior to the collision, reports said. 
Sheriff’s investigators said the elder 
Castillo received relatively minor in­ juries and the truck driver was not injured. 

H e can't dvpcntl on designed vc/.’ an aircraft carrier that isn't cecil 

Congress. It was approved by voice vote and sent to the Senate. 
The vole may end the era of the nu­ clear aircraft carrier because the Sen­ ate is even more likely to go along with the decision than the House was. 
Opponents, including Rep. Robert L. 
F. Sikes, D-Fla., called the decision a mistake, arguing that the smaller ships exist only on paper and there is no firm design for them even there. 
“ This is a bird in hand,” Sikes said of the nuclear carrier. “ We can't depend on an aircraft carrier that isn t even designed yet." 
Other opponents such as Rep. 
Samuel S. Stratton, D-N.Y., said the vertical short takeoff and landing air­ craft that the smaller carrier will handle also is not yet ready for Navy operations. 
Mahon 
But House Appropriations Commit­ tee Chairman George IL Mahon. I)- 
Tex., said President Carter is "mov ing away toward the smaller ships and more ships so we can cover the oceans of this earth." 

"I'm for this recission because I’m strong for defense as I ve always been," Mahon said. 
Three nuclear aircraft carriers are in various stages of construction and the USS Enterprise already is in operation. 
Adm. James L. Holloway, chief of naval operations, told a Senate sub­ committee this week that arrangement will give the Navy 12 aircraft carriers in the early 198os, which he said will continue to be central to U.S. naval strategy now planned into the 199os 

But opponents said tilt* Joint Chiefs of Staff still have a position paper calling for 18 carriers and contended the Navy should get the fifth nuclear carrier now and the smaller carriers iii the future. 
The fifth carrier had an estimated cost of $2.2 billion 
Congress had approved a total $33o million last year to start work on it. and the $288.4 million remaining after the $81.8-million cut will be trans­ ferred to the three carriers still under construction. 
Couple convicted o f killing daughter 

ATHENS. Twin. (A P) — Ronald and 
Wanda Gibson Maddux were convicted 
Thursday of murdering Mrs. Mad­ dux's 4-year-old daughter, the child the couple had })een jailed for abusing three years ago. 
The couple was sentenced to serve 99 years and one day in the state peni­ tentiary. 
The jury deliberated only 43 minutes before returning the verdict 
Mrs 
Maddux burst into tears, while her husband stared straight ahead 
The two were charged after Melisha 
Gibson's battered body was found last 
Oct. 13 on a wet mattress iii the fami­ ly's unheated living room 
Storm 
Hie case created a storm of outrage about the state's handling of abused children. The little girl was taken away from her mother and step-father when they were jailed before, but she was returned til them last May alter social workers said Melisha would be safe with Hu* couple.

NEW YORK (A P) - Richard Nix­ on's memoirs will b e published iii hardcover iii t h e United S t a t e s and 
Canada bv Crossett & Dunlap Inc., t h e company said Thursday, 
W illiam Sarnoff. chairman of 
Warner thinks. which hu-> the world­ wide publishing rights to Nixon's me­ moir*. made the joint announcement with Harold Ruth. president of G r o s ­ s e d ii Dunlap 
The price which Grossed & Dunlap paid Wartier B«M>ks for the hardcover publishing rights was not announced 
Publication of tin- hardcover edition of Nixon's memoirs is expected early 

 iii 1978. Roth said He said plans for the memoirs had been reviewed last week 
’in a series of meetings with Nixon at 
Ins home iii San Clemente. Calif, 
Thursday's announcement is the second agreement made iii the United 
States for Nixon's memoirs since 
Warners Books bought the rights in 
1974 
Previous!), the New York limes purchased worldwide serialization rights 
Iii addition, several major foreign publications deals have been made, including British, French, Japanese, 
Arabic, Dutch aud Spanish. 

District Atty. Gen. Richard Fisher had asked the jury to give both the 
Madduxes a life sentence in the state penitentiary. He said Maddux com­ mitted the murder but Mrs Maddux was equally guilty of aiding and abet­ ting the crime. 

Prosecutors contended that Maddux had let Melisha lie naked on a hard­ wood floor all night Oct. ll, had forced her to march through the house the following day. had beaten her and had repeatedly forced her to drink hot saute. 

A pathologist testified Melisha died of internal bleeding from a ruptured kidney. He said it would have required 
"severe fort e" to cause such an injury. 

Attorneys tor Maddux contended that M r s Maddux beat the child to death and lied to cover the crime, while Mrs. Maddux' attorneys con­ te luted that sh e feared her husband so much that she dared not help lier child 

Fisher, iii his closing arguments, said: "Ronald Maddux tortured and murdered that little girl. And the little things a dutiful wife does fur her man while in the course of his evil conduct make her equally guilty of second de­ gree murder" 

Fisher said Mrs. Maddux made love to her husband while her child lay naked on a hardwood floor, cooked supper as he beat the child and rubbed alcohol on Ins shoulder after he had beaten Melisha for a full day. 

"She did all she could do in ibis tor­ turous period of Melisha s life,” said 
Mrs Maddux* defense attorney, Don 
Reid. "She may be guilty of l>etng a poor mother, but that docs not make her guilty of being a murderess 

Maddux' attorney, Leroy Phillips, charged that Mrs, Maddux Iud lied const a fitly throughout the trial. 

Expert on gumbo 

W hen people up and down the Texas G ulf Coast debate whose seafood gumbo is the best, 
E lb o w " Hanna has his backers. Elbow s gumbo eliminates the middleman* — he not only cooks the gumbo, lie catches all the seafood that goes into it. Elbow and Venita Hanna run a shrimp and fishing boat and a restaurant at 

Sargent Beach, on the G ulf southeast of Bay City. In Saturday s Express News, 

G e o r g e and Bonnie Carmack tell about the Hannas — and their dancing dog. — 
Photo by Bonnie Carmack.

Hoods Senate offices 

 w a r m i n g J O N P O S ! i t X V K . I 

WASHINGTON — A massive con-- serval ive mail and telephone cam­ paign against the nomination of Paul 
(*. Warlike to head the I S. arms control team Hooded Senate off lees as the Senate decided Thursday to vole on 
Waruke Wednesday 
Republicans opposing Warnkes no­ mination to head the Arms Control and 
Disarmament Agency and lead the 
I S learn in strategic arms negotia­ tions vv uh the Sos lets abandoned their threat ol a filibuster in return for a 

 and debate that will begin Thursday run until the vote lute Wednesday. 
The decision, worked out by the 
S«‘date leadership, apiw ared to insure 
Warnke s confirmation to both |M»sts, hut conservative spokesmen said their opposition to Warlike should signal

 target l i s ts and sci r funneled through organizations bk*- tin IV V ., peopu and when I found oat tiler*' ti- people in this town w h o w a : t 
I. ovm badly enough they want to , e tins in­ competence forward tor t h e ii -t u n, portant policy making p o s i t io n s in Hie city, then I have to begin questioning their intentions." 
Dement, one of the founders of ABC who resigned from the organizationV board after deciding to run for office,- said campaign aide .bindle McArthur had been informed by an ABC repre­ sentative that ABC was endorsing him and Steen. 
He said, however, since he became a candidate, he hasn’t attended any ABC meetings and isn’t privy to what the organization is doing. 
L o u is Pitluk s a i d The Pitluk Group is not representing ABC a s such. 
Swipe 
On another front. Dement took a swipe at opponent Hartman. He said that the council had sat for 23 months without offering any utility rate relief, hut Hartman Thursday "all of a sud­ den made a lug plea" for relief of the rate-payer by cutting utility costs with part of the money CPS pays the city in lieu of taxes. 
" It ’s absolutely nothing hut a politi­ cal move,” Dement complained, 
"since he sat there for 23 months and didn’t worry about the rate-payer. He didn’t do anything until election time. 
Hartman, meanwhile, has called a press conference for 9 a. rn. Friday in the Gunter Hotel's Texas Room. 
On yet another front, David C. Brown 
Jr.. candidate for the council from 
District 8, will open his campaign headquarters in the Colonies Mall, 37oo 
Colony Dr., with an open house starl­ ing at 7 p. rn. Friday. He’ll serve free coffee at the headquarters from IO a. in. to 12 noon Saturday.

Light up your face with color 

By JENNIFER ANDERSON 
Have you ever been to a party where your host or hostess planned the light­ ing effects so well that the guests looked better than you know they really do? 
P la n n e d dim lig h tin g nr candlelight can create an illu­ sion of glam or. But the real tric k is to c r e a te you r own make-up illusions to get that glamor at the office or in the blazing sunlight. 

L earning how to use light correctly when you m ake up. and knowing what colors to use to correct unflattering light you might be in. is a real art. 
F irs t, you should learn to make up flawlessly in daylight. lf you can do that, you can ea­ sily make any of the other cor­ rections for office or evenings out. 
(Frequently women will do their daytime make-up leaning over the bathroom sink, in the worst possible lighting, and wonder why in the clear light of day their make-up is streaked. 

 blotched and overdone.) 
Devote a Saturday afternoon to an experim ental m ake-up session before a window that allows good light. Hold a hand m irro r and go through your entire make-up routine step by step. You’ll be quite amazed at what you see! 
You’ll soon realize that less is better and natural colors like beige, brown, sand and pinks or citrals that have a hint of brown in them are the most natural. 
Sharp, bright blue or acid green eye shadow or any lip­ 

 sticks with a hint of p u rple have to go! You might be sur­ prised. too, to find out just how much blending is necessary to do a flaw less job. 
Now change the lights in your make-up area at home to make the lighting strong and even. 
Check your daylight make-up jolt under these lights. 
That’s the effect you’ll want to achieve every day. Armed with the rig h t sh ad es of m ak e-up and a new way of looking at your face, you should be able to improve your office appearance by 1o(1 percent.

SA W Y ER 

The light-hearted 
Junior League “ Re­ flections 1977'' show and cocktail supper was a colorful stroll through San Anton­ io's parks over the past IOO years. 
V illita 
Assem bly 
Building had so many balloons tied to chair- backs and floating above the multi-colored checked gingham table­ cloths it took a little care to cross the ballroom. 
Wide streamers in red. orange, lime, turquoise, blue and yellow were looped from a center co­ lumn to form a canopy. 
The stage resembled a gazebo w it Ii its lattice work, greenery and hanging baskets. 

Mrs. Tim Musgrave brew “ m oney” away while wearing a brief ostume with “ dollar bills” all over it. She was me of the walking ads for he National Bank of 
Commerce. 

Rooster 

Toby Tale got a lot of aughs in her rooster ces­ ium' for Church’s Fried 
Ti ic* ken. 
When she lapped her wings, her tail leathers wiggled. 

Ed Griepenkerl got a omul of applause for his solo in the Bowen’s Island skit. and Sherrie Kleck was the star of the Hoop 
Boo Be Boo Park. Flap­ pers i i i short, fringed sheaths did a realistic shimmy enlivened with some high kicks. 

David and B e lly Co- 

 megys with children, 

(ius. Hallie and David. sang and darn ed to their tiitar music as a family unloving Maverick Park 
III ISS?- 
At the finale, co-chair­ men Linda McSueen and 
Ellen Johnson got bou­ quets of yellow roses amid a standing ovation. 
Linda wrote the show. 
Out on the patio. Dale 

 and Mertie Wood told of their trip to Aspen “ ski­ ing on rocks, trees and a little snow, ‘way up.” A better trip was the one they took to Puerto Hico last spring 
Mertie hit a s ui jackpot on mu* of the nickel slot machines and flew to St. Thomas on her 

 white fringed shawl. Two years ago he moved to 
San 
Antonio from 
Bersailles, Ky. Now re­ tired, he was one of the few civ ilian technical ad- 
\ isors iii Alaska and the 
Aleutians during World 
War ll. 

Jean Blaylock was with 
Ed Cobb. a San 
Antonian since August vv hen he moved here from 
Houston. He’s the new ow ner of a company that reconditions 55-gallon barrels after liquids are shipped in them. 
The Frank Galinos sat with the John Monfreys. 
Galino teaches at St. 
Mary’s Hall. 

Ball 

The Pink Elephant Ball will begin with cocktails at 7:5o p.m. Friday in the 
San 
Antonio Country 
Club, and a buffet dinner will follow. 

Son. John Tower is scheduled to speak. 
E l­ ton 
Kline and his orchestra will play music. for dancing. The Texas 
Federation of Republican 
Women of Bexar County 
(six clubs) is sponsoring the annual hall. 

Mrs. Skip Fuhrmann is general chairman of the hall. Assisting are 
Mines. Jack Sims. spon­ sors; Richard Eddleman.

Wade 

Smaller!, trip arrange­ ments; John VV. Ballard, decorations;

Dwight C. llageman. in­ vitations. I . A. Deaxon. table program s; and 
Helen Moran, treasurer.

Argyle, including 

Paul

Dick Killian and M ait­ land Rutledge.

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Friday March 4 1977 
Acting assertive in the bedroom 

By JEAN BAER 
Ju s t as you can learn to m ak e the assertive social r e ­ quest “ I want to so out to dinner ton­ ight,” you can learn to communicate your desires in the sexual area. 
Good sox may bo only part of tho good Ufo, but it iv far too important for 

 any woman to wait for it to happon. 
But many women do 
‘‘watt for it to happen." 
Why? 
Societal brainwashing has had a severe effect in the sexual area. Many women still believe the 
“ old wives* tales" and taboos : “ Masturbation is b ad " . . . "M e n need more sex than women" . 
. . “ I t ’s tho wom an’s fault if the man is im ­ p o tent"^ . . “ Grin and 

ART EXHIBITION 
CLAY M CG AUG H Y 
AND 
PERRY SHANKLE, JR. 
M ARCH 6 TO M A R CH 21 
RECEPTION H O N O R IN G THE 
ARTISTS SU NDAY, M A R CH 6, 
4 TO 7 P.M. 

 glosser's art gallery 

21 N. M A IN 
PHONE 732-1 121, 

 bear it" . . . “ Sex is a woman’s duty.” 
Says 
Dr. 
Beverly 
Hotehner, executive dir­ ector of the Conter for 
Human Concerns, a sex­ uality resource center in 
St. Louis, “ Women are now at the stage of talk­ ing more openly about sex, but for most of them things haven’t changed. 
“ Women are trained from Day One to be pas­ sive. The early injunc­ tions are so potent and pervasive that it’s diffi­ cult for women to have different behaviors as a d u l t s . " ng 

Some women feel they don’t have the right to sexual pleasure—that’s a male prerogative. They' are brought up to be pleasing, to stifle their own wants. 
Asking for what they need in bed would be 
“ unbearably selfish" and 

“ unladylike, so they spend years suppressing desires and faking or­ gasms to make their partners “ happy.” 
Meanwhile, this pre­ tense makes them angry, and inner resentment builds until it stifles their ability to relax during sex. 
According to Dr. Helen 

Kaplan, clinical associate professor of psychiatry, 
Cornell University Medi­ cal College, “ The woman who enjoys sex has al­ ways been looked down on. 
“ Yes, the cultural cli­ mate is changing and to­ day many very young girls are at ease with their own sexuality—but many more women still are not." 

Says Dr. Alan Gold­ stein, associate professor of psychology and psy­ chiatry at Temple Uni­ versity School of Medi­ cine, “ Despite the so­ called ‘new morality,’ the societal pressures are still there." 
As Masters and John­ son have said, "The most unfortunate misconcep­ tion our culture has as­ signed to sexual func­ tioning is the assumption by both men and women that men by divine gui­ dance and infallible in­ stinct are able to discern exactly what a woman wants sexually and when she wants it. 
“ Probably this fallacy has interfered with na­ tural sexual interaction as much as any other single factor.” 
Some women suffer from one, some, or all of a series of fears. 
Fear of hurting him. If you say or do anything 

K '- Z W - - ' 
, 
W ; g&V 
% 
J / 
& 
* ■ 

WILLIAM MASTERS 

 that appears c ritica l, you’ll hurt that tender male ego. And you can’t do that. “ Better to suffer in silence,” you rationa­ lize. 
Fear of being thought unfem inine or aggres­ sive. 
Fear of rejection. 
Fear ot total abandon­ ment. lf you give your* 

VIRGINIA JOHNSON 

 self completely, you real­ ly make a commitment. 
Some women can’t do this. 
Competition 

Fear of competition. If you have a desirable man and a fulfilling sex life, other women will try to hurt you, to take him from you. 

Thus, you reason you 
"mustn’t have this good life so that this dreadful tiling will not happen.” 
Often this irrational be­ lief is purely a rationali­ zation for doing the things you’ve been trained to do. 
Characteristics 

What arc the charac­ teristics of the sexually assertive woman? 

—She knows her own body. She understands it well* enough to know her sexual wants. 

—She is comfortable with her own body. This doesn't mean you have to be ‘ii years old or possess 
34-24-34 proportions, It does mean you feel proud and confident about your appearance. 

You know men find you attractive. 
Says 
Dr. 
Kaplan, “ People’s emo­ tions are transmitted. A 

 man can tell if a woman feels sexy.” 

—She takes responsibi­ lity for her own sexual well-being. She feels the gratification of her own desires is just as impor­ tant as the pleasure of her partner. 
—She is not bound by the sexual dictates of her parents, relatives, friends, culture. She be­ lieves, “ If it makes me feel good and I like my­ self for doing it. it is okay." 
—She can com m uni­ cate her desires to her part tier — gently. opon Iy . appropriately, and in a nondefensive manner. 

—She is willing to take risks—of judgment, c ri­ ticism . possible reje c­ tion. 
She is alw ays willing to try new things that may make her a more sensual person and provide increased fulfill­ ment. 

-A

 geared to changing tim es and values. 
O v er 4,ooo h a i r c u t t e r s a r o u n d th e world have joined his Paul M itchell 
Cutting Club to keep up with his ideas and methods. 

Paul Mitchell, who opened the first cut-and-hlow dry beauty salon in the country in New York City, is at F ro st's 
Beauty Salon in North S tar Mall F ri­ day. 
T h is h air c o n s u lta n t, now of New 
York and Hawaii, left his native E ng­ land in the m ini-skirt era for M anhat­ tan. He took h a ird re s sin g out of the doldrum s with high-fashion, precision cutting techniques. 
Now known as the h a irc u tte r^ h air­ c u t t e r . M itc h e ll c r e a t e s h a i r c u t s 

A month ago Mitchell opened an ad ­ vanced training school for professional haircu tters in New York. He is on a cross-country tour of Seligm an & Latz beauty salons to hone the skills of their h airstylists and serve as fashion a d ­ visor to salon clients.

Elegant Printed Chenille Velvet! 

Exquisite Quilt Cut Velvet! 
For a really elegant look . . . one that's definitely out of the ordinary, you'll want to see this brand new grouping in rich tones of gold, orange, rust, and brown on a white background! It's the kind of a group that brings bright cheerful color to a room that might otherwise be somber. You can choose the matching sofa and loveseat . . . each with reversible seat, back and arm cushions . . . outline quilted for luxury. O r you can choose the fabulous sofa and two chenille velvet chairs in matching solid orange tone. 
Either way, it s a beauty of a buy! 

Sofa and Loveseat or Sofa with two chairs 

The group below has been the “star" of our show for some time, now! 
The long 4 cushion sofa and matching loveseat are covered in a sumptuous cut velvet in tones of soft, tasteful greens in a floral pattern. 
To add an even more luxurious look the cushions are thickly quilted to foam! The two traditional chairs are solid green velvet, perfectly mat­ ched to the sofa pattern. You could hardly ask for a lovelier or more versatile group ... and ifs on sale now, during Lack's Main Event Sale!

W ell, first he had to hire people with the knowledge to teach his offensive arid defensive system. 
So he rushed out and hired Nebras­ ka's defensive coordinator. S M I"s de­ fensive line coach. Alabam a's tight end coach. Auburn s offensive coor­ dinator and. finally. Texas’ offensive back coach 
He took a few months to explain his system to these assistants and then spent weeks studying film s of his re­ turning prospects. 
Starting this week. Holtz went to work. He says the goal is to accomplish six things i i spring training. 
"First, we want to im prove every player on the team , fundam entally. 
Second, we want to give every voting man on our team a chance to win a position. Third, we want to evaluate our personnel in terms of what each blaver can best (lit offensively and de­ fensively. 
“ Fourth, we want the players to get to know us a s coaches. Fifth, we want to develop an attitude of each player working to the maximum of Ins ability 
Finally, we want to find out who wauls tit win and who is w illing to do the things necessarv to w in .” explains 
Holt/

Coogs, Tech survive 

By K E V IN O K E E F F E 

Of THI EXPRESS STAM 

HOUSTON — Mark Trammell norm ally known as Houston’s other guard, was the main man in tho second half and guided the C ougars to a 9H-77 victory over Texas A&M in Southwest 
Conference Tournament action 
Thursday night ut The Summit. 

Tram m ell, six-foot junior from 
Dayton. Ohio. had 12 points iii Hic second half, including six during a 14-2 surge which ended the Aggie s hopes iii the game. 

Iii T h u r s d a y s second game. Texas lech whipped Baylor HH-57 to earn a berth against Houston at S p.m. Friday night Ttie winner plays Arkansas Sa­ turday night. 

“ When Tram m ell carne iii and made two or three baskets, that was probably the turning point.” Cougars’ 
« ouch Guy Lewis admitted “ But I did not start lo leel comfortable until there were just 4U seconds left. 

“ We had been up and down the floor about three o r four tunes without doing anything when Tram m ell took charge." 

“ I thought the Iwst hall club won." 
Aggie Coach Shelby M e tc a lf said. showing a slight grim ace. “ Houston has a good club. 
They are leum-urtented Even (O tis) Birdsong. 
He gets Ins points, but he is a team player." 
Houston led by live. HO-55, when the

The Net set 

BY JE F E (.KOSSMAN 

O r ( M f EXPRESS STATT 
UNIONDALE, N Y. — Only a person who sleeps with a copy el the NBA Register under Ins pillow could tell you about the 
New York Nets’ roster. 

Only four players remain from last season s ABA championship team. 
Ami p e rh a p s least known, but most promising, guard Bubbles Hawkins 
The Spurs face the Nets Friday at the Nassau County Coliseum. 
Hawkins, a second-year pro from Illinois Slate, was cut by the Golden 
State W arriors during training camp 
The Nets, undermanned at guard when Tiny Archibald went out with a broken loot. pu ked up Hawkins on the recommendation of former Net aud current Golden State star Rick Barry 
And the results have been stunning. Hawkins, usually the first guard off the Nets bench, is tile team s second-leading scorer with 19 iroints a game. 

/ s n R S . S K I S c la s h U n tig h t til 7:9.» 

And he has a single-game high of 14 points. 
When the name Hawkins began appearing iii the small j»rmt of Imix scores iii newspapers around the country , many assumed < outlie Hawkins was making a comeback. 
I never realized we get almost 29 points a game from him ," smiled 
Neis" Coach Kevin Lougherv. 
"There's no substitute at this level for speed and quickness," says former Boston Celtic great Bob Consy. “ And the kid has it 
I just went back home to Detroit after getting cut and waited to sec what would happen.” said Hawkins, one of six Nets" left-handers 
Hawkins' given name is Robert His brother tagged him with Bubbles because he was i ne! 11 led to pull practical jokes 
S P I K S S H O R T S : 
The Spurs, once given to passive resistance on the road, have now won two straight on this five-game road trip after losing the o|M*iier to Atlanta San Antonio has won six of its last nine road games 
The Nets. meanwhile, are better on the road (11-29) than at home (9-22). 
Their 2o-4J record is the worst iii the NBA. Starting Net guard Al Skinner is expected to miss Ins fourth straight game Friday night with a sprained ankle. 

Hogs must learn to put it in air

Blit in preparation for a new year.

Fin ley s $4oo,9oo sale of pitcher Paul 
Lm dblad from Oakland to the Texas 
Rangers Thursday. But Kulm said lie'll keep a sharp eye on future dealing by the feisty ow tier of the A's.

Vt a three-hour hearing Wednesday in Dallas.

Ins ball club

GREENSBORO. 
N C. (A P) - Marc lavaroni hit a tur­ naround bank shot from close range with two seconds to go as defending champion Virginia upset second-seeded 
Wake Forest 59-57 in the first game of the 
Atlantic Coast Con­ ference basketball tournament Thurs­ day. 

Wake Forest’s Skip 
Brown missed a desper­ ation .innipsliot from half court at the buzzer. lavaroni’s shot came nine seconds after Dea­ con freshman Frank 
Johnson converted two pressure free throws that tied the game 57-57. 
The 
Deacons had trailed 4S-44 with 1o:18 to go. tint outscored Virgin­ ia O O over the next fixe minutes to take its first lead since late in the first half. 
Wake Forest finished the season 2o-7.

SPECIAL TO IHE IX PR (5,6 
MALIBU, Calif. — Pepperdine shocked Trinity Thursday, 6-3, spoiling the top-rated Tigers’ meeting with UCLA Saturday. 

The shocking loss followed on the heels of T rinity’s fi-3 victory over 
Southern California Wednesday. FSC had beaten Pepperdine earlier by the same score. 
The lOth-ranked Waves won each of tile tup three singles events in handing the Tigers only their second loss in ll matches. 
Eddie Edwards ut Pepperdine hand­ ed Larry (Jottfried a 7-5, 3-fi. 6-3 set­ back in No. I singles. 
Pepperdine had to come from behind but won both the Nos. 2-3 singles as Leo 
Paylin stopped Tony Giammalva. 2-6. 
(4-2. 7-6 and Shiran Saresh halted Erick 
Iskersky. 1-6. 6-4. 6-1 

Ben MeKoun and Dave Benson in 
Nos 4-5 singles won their matches for 
Trinity. McKown whipped Craig 
Edwards, 6-3, 7-5. while Benson rallied for a 6-7. 7-6, 7-6 nod over Maurice 
Hunter. 
Dean Graham of Pepperdine defeat­ ed Mike Davidson. 6-1. 6-o, in No. 6 singles. 
The Waves won two of the three doubles. Trinity’s only victory coming by McKown and Iskersky, who shack­ led Hunter and Graham in straight 6-3 sets. 
Eddie Edwards and Paylin handed 
Gottfried and Giammalva a 6-1. 7*5 defeat, while (raid 
Edwards and 
Saresh tacked a 6-2. 2-6, 6-1 setback on 
Davidson and Benson. 
Trinity is off Friday, then returns to action against UCLA at 3 p rn. Satur­ day. San Antonio time. Tliat match concludes the Tigers’ West Coast tour.

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Fridoy March 4 1977 in Gloves 

Continued from Page IF and Raymond Valenzuela of CPR won canvas with a left midway through the bouts that both drew ovations, first round, then sent his opponent 
Pastran, who was knocked down in sprawling to the floor again with a the first round, rallied to upset Gilbert crushing left-right combination at the Favella of PPR in their opening feath- end of the round. erweight match. 
Referee Charles Shaw felt Gutierrez 
Valenzuela and Rani Rangel of the had had enough and stopped the bout East Side Boxing Club fought tooth and before the bell for the start of the nail before Valenzuela emerged the second round. victor by decision. Both fighters 
The 2.5oo fans (1.ooo paid) received tagged each other at will, but Valen- some disappointment. zuela got the better of the scoring 
The four Open Division heavyweight punches, matches, all involving boxers from the 
The tournament continues with 59 
Seguin Boys Club, were defaulted bouts F rid a y . because the Seguin fighters did not 
Charlie Brehn, an Independent, and make either the IO a m.-noon or the Steve Campos of the West Side Y. 
5-6.3o p.m. weigh-ins. proved to be the crowd-pleasers while 
Robert Reynosa of Blackies and Tommy Escobedo of Blackies and 
Garza Boxing Club, the 1976 Novice Garza won a decision over teammate 
Division heavyweight king, won his Gilbert Garza in the most scientific match over Pedro Aleman of Seguin because of the costly error. 
Defending champions Juan Ro­ driguez of the Eagle Pass Parks & 
Recreation. Pedro Cantu of the Eagle 
Pass Boxing Club and Danny Favella of City Parks & Recreation won their opening-night matches. 
Favella provided the evening's second knockout. 
Favella, the defending Open welter­ weight champion, started back on the right track by disposing of Lupe Ran­ gel of the West Side YMCA with 1:14 remaining in the second round. 
Favella. who floored Rangel earlier in the round with a left, put his op­ ponent to the canvas for good with a sharp right. 
Rodriguez, last year's Novice Di­ vision featherweight king, won a de­ cision over Angel Chavez of City Parks 
& Recreation. 
Cantu, the defending Novice ban­ tamweight champ, collected a couple of knockdowns in earning a decision over Joe Hernandez of the West Side 
YMCA. 
Alfredo Pastran of the West Side Y 

 bout of the evening. 
Brehn brought cheers from the crowd with his turning in circles in earning a split decision over Ruben 
Gonzales of the South Side Boys Club in a Novice middleweight bout. 
Campos, much shorter and stockier than his opponent, won the battle of 
David and Goliath with James Kovacs, an Independent, in the Novice light- heavyweight match. Campos stunned his eager foe with timely lefts to earn a unanimous decision.

RUN FOR YOUR LIFE 

Running and jogging is the simplest most effective way to exercise. Become physically fit! And 

 as Spring is so close, now is the time to get out, enjoy life, and become fit in this beautiful Texas country through Man s most basic form of exercise. 

Jogging is available to anyone, male or female, young 

 or old, and so little is required. 

The only equipment required for jogging is 

 adequate foot wear, and it is of major importance. 

Today, new innovations in shoe manufacture make it 

 possible to meet your specific jogging needs. At Mursch we have 

 one of the most complete inventories of top quality running and jogging 

 shoes, making it possible for us to 

 cater to your needs. 
/ 
C S u 

- t it ? 

For example, the Nike LD-1ooo features a 

 superwide, waffled heel and sole, offering unsurpassed cushioning and stability. With this 

 shoe, you can exercise without sacrificing your 

 feet. It retails for $39.95. 

The Nike Waffle Trainer is a bit more 

 conservative than the LD-1ooo. It s stability and foot protection remain excellent, yet 

 as a trainer it is light enough for long distance racing. A beautiful shoe, 

 retailing at $27.95. 
The Nike Sting is an outstanding d is­ tance racing shoe. 
Nylon back, perforated suede front for ventila­ tion, and a flared heel for stability, all combine to offer reliability and main- tainance to the racing foot. Price: $34.95. 
In addition to Nike, we carry shoes by Adidas, Puma, Tiger, Brooks, New 
Balance, and others. Our professional sales staff will be happy to help you se­ lect the right model to fit your needs. 
Come see us today. It s your life. Start running for it!

Jitters tough to beat 

By JOHN HINES 
Of THE EXPRESS STAff 

It will be a pair of we 11-hu­ la need squads which hit the court at Blossom Athletic ( enter at noon Saturday when Corpus 
Christi Moody (35-2) and Austin 
Reagan (2o-11) collide in the se­ cond s e m ifin a l g a m e of the 
(la ss AAA A Region IV Tourney. 

All five starters for both teams arc hittin g in d o u b le f ig u re s and su c h quantity lias produced an average of HI 

 points a g a m e for Moody and 78 for 
Reagan. 
While Moody has ap p e ared in two pre\ ions regionals, reaching the finals last year. Reagan won its first district b a s k e tb a ll c h a m p i o n s h i p in school history after building its athletic fame on football (three state titles). 

Theft th e R a i d e r s r e a l l y hit th e jackpot with an 8o-74 overtime v ictory oyer d e f e n d i n g r e g io n a l c h a m p i o n 
Victoria to qualify as one of the four teams for the BAC meet. 
“ We had the playoff jitters and were tight and they jumped out in front us to lead by 14 points at halftime.” Reagan 
( oath Gail Simpson recounted of the 

V ictoria game. 
“ We cam e back determ ined iii the se c o n d h a l f . ” he w e n t on. “ a n d chipped away with two points here and two there. With four seconds left in regulation we tied the score for the first tim e on M ark T a y l o r ’s ju n ip e r from the top. 
“ Then in the o vertim e we got tin* lead, went into our delay g a m e and produced on our free throws.” 
He said the biggest factor in the se­ cond-half rally was that. “ We tighth- ened up our man-to-man defense and kept them to one shot; they were get­ ting two or three in the first half. 
" F o r us to win Saturday, we'll have 

 to play tremendous defense, hit a good percentage of our shots, and not take any bad shots, lf we do that, we can come out a winner.” 
Moody bas now won 17 .straight since losing to Burbank, fil-49, in the se m i­ finals of the San Antonio Tourna m e nt at Alamo Stadium Gym. The other loss was to Houston Madison iii the Corpus 
Christi Tournament finals. 

“ We return nine lettermen from last y e a r ’s 12-man s q u a d , so e x p e r ie n c e has been a big factor." Coach Steve 
(ion/ales said of the T rojans’ success. 

Their personnel will be listed in Sa­ turday’s preview.

(act that we did It at this time should not be taken as on indica­ tion contract talks hove broken down It's lust tho! I will no* be meeting Dave every day and we are obligated to renew it before 
M arch IO.”
