DITTMAR LUMBER A 

Hie Buick Opel 
Car Showdown is coming. 

Wherein Buicks tough, talented Opel takes on four of its better known competitor; in a daring, fender-to-fender companson. 

 w a — 
- ■ . • _ 
■ • ■ * - - 
- ww ny m is Uiiiwffiious 

Our thinking went something like this. We know Buick s Opel is a little dynamo of a car. But apparently we’re the only ones who do. Because when anyone goes out looking for a practical little import, they look real hard at the other cars in this Showdown. But not at ours. Thus, the 5-Car Show ­ down. W e wanted to show you how good our little Opel is. So much so, 

W hat cfid we fest? 
The Showdown covers a number of areas including; Human Engi­ neering, Utility, and Operating 
Efficiency. We figured that by the time each of those areas had been explored, we d have examined most of the major issues involved in choosing a new car— imported or otherwise. 
In the process, you’ll find out things like whose car is roomiest and whose car has the greatest estimated range on a tank of gas. 
Plus neat little tidbits like which car has the biggest trunk. Which car has the largest gas tank. 
Even which car has the most desirable maintenance schedule. 

Who Vian? 
You’ll find out soon enough. 
Because we’ll be running a series of ads in this newspaper that will cover each area of the testing. Be on the lookout for them. 
At this point, we should mention one thing. We entered this whole 
5-Car Showdown with no idea of 

The combatants fender-to-fender. whether we would win, or come in second, or even come in last. We were confident that Opel would do well, though. So we were willing to throw the little rascal to the mercy of the Showdown officials. 

Let the Showdown begin. 

 that we’ve put our car — and their c a r s - through a series of independ­ ently supervised tests. Just to see who’s who and what s what. 

Scientific instruments monitored various aspects of the Showdown. ffic tests Dmscd • 
No, no, a thousand times, no. 
We enlisted the aid of an inde­ pendent authority, who acquired the cars and supervised the tests.. 
And looking over his shoulder was a member of the editorial staff of 
Car and Driver magazine 
The tests were conducted at the 
General Motors Desert Proving 
Grounds in Mesa, Arizona. That way, we could be sure of the sophistication and accuracy of both the instrumentation and the procedures. 

Opel. We think it’s good enough to take on the world. 
We wanted to show that our Opel can hold its own against its better established competitors. That it should be considered when you wander out to shop for one of these little devils. 
In any case, whether we won or lost a given test, we’ll be reporting the results to you. At times, that should prove painful 
W ish us luck. 

Ag ' 
‘ 
/TST*’ STY 

The combatants, left to right: Toyota Corolla, Subaru DL. VW Rabbit, Datsun B-21o, and Ope! 
IHE BUICK OPEL 5-CAR SHOWDOWN

(AP) — Lee Trevino and five other candidates were nom inated Thurs­ day for membership in tin- Modern Era category in the World (jolt Hall of 
Fame.

B illy 
Casper, 
Bobby 
Locke. Louise Suggs. 
Peter Thomson and the late Lawson Little. These five are repeat ca n d i­ dates. Tres mo is eligible for the first tim e this year.

I frill

Committee. Ball was the

G olf lead captured by Rogers 

ORLANDO, Fla. (AF) - Bill “ B uck” 
Rogers, another in the seemingly endless line of young men dominating the tour this year, one-putted IO tim es on the way to six-under-par BH and took the first-round lead Thursday in the $2oo,ooo Florida Ci­ trus Open Golf Tournament. 

" h n i o i n e d U.S. voted top skater 

Franklin top trackster 

George Franklin, form er Sam Hous­ ton High School star, leads the Texas 
A&I track team in scoring this year with 3h points after two meets. 
F ranklin ran on the second-place 
44o-yard re la y team and finished fourth in the 1oo-meter dash for 12 points last weekend at the Lam ar 

Invitational in Beaumont. He now has 
3o points for the year. 

Larry Collins, form erly of Edison, is in second place with 25 points. 
The .lavalinas p articipate in the 
Border Olympics in Laredo this wee­ kend. 

Rogers, the tour in 1974 and has yet to win, twice reeled o ff s trin g s of three consecutive birdies as he posted his ca re er-b e st opening round. 
“ I keep reading in the papers almost every day w hat the veterans are saving about the young g u y s .” said R ogers, a bubbly, outgoing native of Texarkana. Tex., and one of the many U niver­ sity of Houston products on the tour. 
“ The thing is. players 
.joining the to u r now. either fresh out of college or from the m ini-tours, have an awful lot of ex­ perience. They know how to play when they get here. 
R ogers, who had to survive tile rigors of the 
Monday qualifying round to gain a spot -iii the tournament field, held a one-stroke lead over 
Mexican V icto r Regala­ do,

TOKYO (A P ) - Six- tfpn-ypar-uld Linda Fra- tianne of Northridge. Ca­ lif., won t he 1977 Wo­ m en’ s 
W orld 
F ig u re 
S kating C ham pionship 
Thursday, saving herself with grace and technical control after a fall in the im portant free skating event. 
M eanwhile, V la d im ir 
K ovalev of the Soviet 
Union traced the best compulsory figures at the start of the men’s com­ petition and a Sov iet pair was un its way to winning the ice dancing title after the third day of competi­ tion. 
M iss F ra tia n n e . the current C S. cham pion, received a total of RI or­ dinals and 189 2H points, which means that eight of the nine judges gave her firs t place and one gave her second. 
She was beaten in the free s k a tin g by a 
L’J-year-old Soviet g ir l, 
Yelena Yodorezova, after the damaging fall in at­ tempting a triple salchow lum p. 
She got up, however, and flew suc- cesslully into a triple toe loop.

Oxygen affects a yawn 

Dear Dr. Thosteson: I arn a 68-year-old female retiree who has been in good health all my life. I recently suffered from a respiratory problem for several weeks. On my most recent checkup I was found to be 
'well. 
« My problem is excessive yawning. Throughout the day at various intervals I feel tin* need to yawn even though I am not in need of sleep. My doctor could 
.shed no light on this. Do vou have an answer? — 
F YU. 
9 i ' a wiling is one of 
J$ose involuntary breathing quirks about which we know little. 
"Another thing is sighing. 
S i b yawning there is a 
’f-aking-in of air. This deep breath does supply extra oxygen and helps relieve the body of excessive carbon diox­ ide. Too. the muscular activity in yawning and stretching can relieve tension and cause some relaxation. 
Yawning may occur when one is bored or tired, and it is w ell­ known that a yawn seems somehow “ conta­ gious .“ We don't know why the sight of another person yawning can us to react this way. 
, There can be some connection between yawning aud the need of the body for extra oxygen to restore 
"the carbon dioxide balance. Thus, sleeping in a 
U*»orIv-ventilated, oxygen-poor room (or working in 
“fille) can cause the phenomenon. 
Whether your yawning sessions are related to your 
/recent respiratory problems is debatable. But you flight be checked for low thyroid activity or possibly anemia, which can produce a subtle fatigue. 
Also, your retirement may have altered your phy­ sical activity, not to mention the mental side of tilings (boredom). I find in the Guinness Book of 
World Records (the only source I know of for such oddities) that the record for yawning involves a 
Young girl who yawned for five weeks straight back rn 188.Y Not a word on sighing. 
£ •■Because of the risk of setting off a nationwide round i»l wide yawns that s all I care to say on the 
•subject. 
- Dear Dr. Thosteson: Is there any way you eau 
‘3>rove a man is the natural father of a child? Any blood tests? — M L. 
Blood type tests may show that a man could not 
Miavc liven the father of a specific child. They*cannot establish that a man is the father to the exclusion of others. 

You con S lo p Sin y c T ro u b le !" f> the title of Dr. Thoste%on v 

 booklet, explaining w h at sinus trouble re a lly is a n d w h at can be

A dollar bill looks much bigger when you take it to church than when you take it lo the race trick. 
Declarer lost 5o points in his plav of today's slam At least (hat s the score that went on the opponents' score card. In reality, the loss was much greater Added to the loss were the hidden points he lost by failing to find the best way to play the hand. 
And like the bettor at the race track, declarer prefer­ red to “see" only the 5o points for the one trick set. 
Declarer won the club lead with his ace and drew the op­ ponents' trumps Then he continued the trumps in hopes of getting some infor­ mation about playing the dia­ mond suit. West was a seasoned veteran and he gave declarer what he was looking for. At the first op­ portunity. he discarded the IO of diamonds 
Declarer thought he had his answer and he discarded two low diamonds, one on dum­ my's high club and the other on the high spade Then he made his diamond play from

“ I don't mess around, boy,” commented Rick 
Nelson with a self-depre­ cating grin. 
He was using the line he made famous as the youngest son on T V ’s 
“ The 
Adventures of 
Ozzie and Harriet” to explain his forthcoming appearance in a drama­ tic role. 
“ I'm always eager th get a good dramatic role, and I thought they came up with a good script on this," he continued, re­ ferring to his starring role in “ A Hand for 
Sonny B lu e" on NBC- 
T V ’s 
“ Tales of the 
Unexpected" March 13. 
In the suspense saga. 
Nelson plays a major league baseball pitcher who undergoes a suc­ cessful hand transplant, rebuilds his sports car­ cer. then finds the alien limb taking on a life of its own. 
“ It ’s a weird role, science fiction or the su­ pernatural or whatever, and it was very hard to do," reported Rick. who has shunned the diminu­ tive “ Ricky" since the 
Ozzie and Harriet co­ medy series ended. 
Singing career 
Nelson initially par­ layed his popularity into a singing career, forming a group, performing at nightclubs and on college campuses, garnering a collection of gold re­ cords. 

“ Being on the series with my motlier aud luther — we were on telev ision for about 14 years and the show ran on radio for eight years before that — certainly didn’t do anything to hurt my singing career.” he admitted. 
“ But the show’s been off the air for more than IO years, now, and I ’m still going strong. I ’m singing for people today who don’t remember me from tele­ vision.” 
After establishing his career as a singing star. 
Nelson made Ins TV dra-

 matte debut in an episode of 
“ Owen 
Marshall: 
Counselor at La w " in 
1972. 
“ That was as big a de­ parture from the family series as my Sonny Blue role,” he reported. “ I played a rapist — how’s that for shattering an image of an all-American boy?" 
First drama 
He recalled how he won that first dramatic role: 
“ The producer gave me a script and told me I had an hour to decide whether I could do it. I said ‘yes' without read­ ing the courtroom scene at the end. I think if I had read it, I would have been too scared to do it.” 
While the Owen Mar­ shall role was difficult, 
Rick thinks his upcoming 
“ Tales of the Unexpect­ ed " performance was even more demanding. 
"When tin* hand begins living a life of its own. 
Sonny doesn’t know it,” he explained. “ So there I am, mov ing the hand to do things it shouldn't do, but at the same time my face has to be blank and unconcerned, because I don't even know the hand is moving." 

RICK NELSON 

...guest role 

He paused reflectively. 
“ It wasn’t an easy part to play. But, then. I don’t mess around, boy," he concluded with his fami­ liar grin.

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Friday March 4 1977 
Trail riders fighting cancer 
Soldiers relaxed with gin 

Over 2oo horse lovers will leave San Antonio 
Saturday on a trail ride lo St. Hedwig to benefit the 
Bexar County Chapter of the American Cancer 
Society. 
Riders will check in and camp at the Cow Shed on 
U.S. 87 Friday night, pinner will be served and dancing will follow at the Cow Shed and at the 
Golden Stallion. 

The riders will leave camp at 8 a.m. Saturday for th(‘ American Legion Hall in St. Hedwig with stops along the way for lunch and refreshments. 
Saturday night festivities in St. Hedwig will feature a barbeque and dance. 
Thy Lonesome Steer Arena will hold Sunday's events which include a flag-exchange race. 

Membership fee for the ride is $12. Trail boss will be Col. Leo Booth. Applications are available at 
Louis Feed Mill, 4542 Rigsby St.; Texas Feed Store, 
I HUI ll San Pedro Ave., Stockyards Rimch Supply, 
1B24 S. San Marcos St., and Southside Meadows 
Stables. 8534 Goliad Road. 

ABOVE G R O U N D ^ 
SW IM M ING-POOLS 

Visitors Bureau they had it prin ted and will in ­ clude it in their tourist information packets. 
“ Surprisingly, there is no central source of in­ formation — especially for tourists — on La Vil­ lita,” Zaccaria said of his research. 
As a m e m b e r of the 
San Antonio C o n se rv a ­ tion Society he has a special fondness for his­ toric San Antonio. 
Research 
The chewing gum dis­ covery was a by-product of his extensive research of old n e w sp a p e r c lip ­ pings. library references and historical archives to obtain information on La 
Villita. 
“ I also did a lot of w alking and ta lk in g ," 
Zaccaria added. Ile said he spoke with m any of the shop ow ners about the history of their pro­ perty. “ lf they d id n ’t know. they often knew som ebody who knew somebody who did," he said. 
The b ro c h u re is described by Zaccaria as a detailed outline for a walking tour ol La Villi- 

The fact won't be found stuck in many historical notes, but chewing gum w as b ro u g h t into the 
Southw est by Mexican 
Gen. Antonio Lopez de 
Santa Anna. 
On his various treks across Texas, Santa An­ na had his troops chew­ ing chicle resin for re ­ laxation during the long marches. 
This little known foot­ note and other interest­ ing facts about San An­ tonio and Texas history w ere uncovered by 
J a m e s 
Z a c c a ria , a 
University of Texas at 
San A ntonio g ra d u a te student in environmental studies, during research for a brochure on La Vil­ lita. 
Brochure 
Z accaria, who has an e n v iro n m e n ta l design degree from Pratt Insti­ tu te in 
New 
Y ork, designed and wrote the brochure for an environ­ m e n ta l m a n a g e m e n t course in graphic com ­ munications at UTSA last summer. 
The b ro ch u re so im ­ pressed officials of San 
Antonio's Convention and

& SUPPLIES

FOR ALL POOLS 

 ta. The buildings are identified by n u m b ers and a short text accom­ panies each id en tifica­ tion. 
For instance, the Little 
Church of La V illita, number four in the bro­ chure, was “ built in I HTB by German Methodists. 
Some 31) y e ars e a r lie r 
John Wesley De Vitbiss sought to build a church on the very sam e site. 
The only thing thai lie erected there, however, was a bell which tolled lo call his congregation to worship across tin' river in the court house. Cock lights in Main Plaza fre­ quently d istu rb e d bis sermons." 
A reference to the ( os 
House describes it as the site where Mexican Gen. 
Martin Perfecto de Cos signed articles of de­ feat in 1H35. setting the stage for the Battle of the 
Alamo th ree m onths later 
Landmarks 
Iii all. Zaccaria lists 19 la n d m a rk s in his b ro ­ chure! including the Pa­ s c o del 
Rio and the 
Arneson River Theater, built as a VV PA project iii the 193o's. 
"I uncox i red enough inform ation to w rite three b ro ch u res," Zac­ caria said of his study. 
Zaccaria also studied architecture as a grad­ uate student at Harvard 
University and is in ter­ ested in the architecture of La V illita as well as its historic aspects. 
‘‘San Antonio has some really classic arch itec­ t u r e . " he said. "W e should encourage tour­ ists not only to visit the 
River VV alk. but to got out and see the many re­ m a rk a b le a re a s throughout the citv.”
